{{Merge from |Carbon dioxide removal|date=April 2018|discuss=Talk:Carbon sequestration#Merge_carbon_dioxide_removal_into_this?}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} [[File:Carbon sequestration-2009-10-07.svg|right|thumb|Schematic showing both terrestrial and geological sequestration of carbon dioxide emissions from a coal-fired plant.]]
'''Carbon sequestration''' is the process involved in [[Carbon fixation|carbon capture]] and the long-term storage of [[atmospheric carbon dioxide]]<ref name="SedjoSohngen">{{Cite journal |first1=Roger |last1=Sedjo |first2=Brent |last2=Sohngen |title=Carbon Sequestration in Forests and Soils | journal=[[Annual Review of Resource Economics]] | volume=4 | year=2012 | pages=127–144 |doi=10.1146/annurev-resource-083110-115941 }}</ref> or other forms of [[carbon]] to [[Climate change mitigation|mitigate or defer global warming]]. It has been proposed as a way to slow the atmospheric and marine accumulation of [[greenhouse gas]]es, which are released by burning [[fossil fuel]]s.<ref name=Hodrien>{{cite conference |first=Chris |last=Hodrien |url=http://www.claverton-energy.com/download/137/ |format=PDF |title=Squaring the Circle on Coal – Carbon Capture and Storage |conference=Claverton Energy Group Conference, Bath |date=October 24, 2008 |accessdate=May 9, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531162754/http://www.claverton-energy.com/download/137/ |archive-date=May 31, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Carbon dioxide ({{chem|CO|2}}) is naturally captured from the atmosphere through biological, chemical, and physical processes.<ref name=glossary>{{cite web|url=http://www.neo.ne.gov/statshtml/glossarys.htm |title=Energy Terms Glossary S |publisher=Nebraska Energy Office |accessdate=May 9, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527191416/http://www.neo.ne.gov/statshtml/glossarys.htm |archivedate=May 27, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref> Artificial processes have been devised to produce similar effects,<ref name=glossary/> including large-scale, artificial capture and sequestration of industrially produced {{chem|CO|2}} using subsurface [[Saline water|saline]] [[aquifer]]s, reservoirs, [[ocean water]], aging [[oil field]]s, or other [[carbon sink]]s.
== Description == Carbon sequestration is the process involved in [[Carbon fixation|carbon capture]] and the long-term storage of atmospheric [[carbon dioxide]] ({{chem|CO|2}})<ref name=SedjoSohngen/> and may refer specifically to: * "The process of removing carbon from the atmosphere and depositing it in a reservoir."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://unfccc.int/essential_background/glossary/items/3666.php#C |title=Glossary of climate change acronyms |website=[[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] |accessdate=July 15, 2010 }}</ref> When carried out deliberately, this may also be referred to as [[carbon dioxide removal]], which is a form of [[climate engineering|geoengineering]]. * [[Carbon capture and storage]], where carbon dioxide is removed from [[flue gases]] (e.g., at [[power station]]s) before being stored in underground reservoirs. * Natural [[biogeochemical cycling]] of [[carbon]] between the [[atmosphere]] and reservoirs, such as by [[chemical weathering]] of rocks.
Carbon dioxide may be captured as a pure by-product in processes related to [[petroleum refining]] or from flue gases from [[power generation]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Alberta producers rewarded for use of {{CO2}} in enhanced oil recovery |date=May 25, 2004 |website=PointCarbon |url=http://www.pointcarbon.com/article.php?articleID=3774&categoryID=147 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506083543/http://www.pointcarbon.com/article.php?articleID=3774&categoryID=147 |archive-date=May 6, 2008 |access-date=August 21, 2015}}</ref> {{chem|CO|2}} sequestration includes the storage part of carbon capture and storage, which refers to large-scale, artificial capture and sequestration of industrially produced {{chem|CO|2}} using subsurface [[Saline water|saline]] [[aquifers]], reservoirs, [[ocean water]], aging [[oil field]]s, or other [[carbon sink]]s.
Carbon sequestration describes long-term storage of [[carbon dioxide]] or other forms of [[carbon]] to either [[mitigation of global warming|mitigate or defer global warming]] and [[Avoiding dangerous climate change|avoid dangerous climate change]]. It has been proposed as a way to slow the atmospheric and marine accumulation of [[greenhouse gas]]es, which are released by burning [[fossil fuel]]s.<ref name="Hodrien" />
Carbon dioxide is naturally captured from the atmosphere through biological, chemical or physical processes. Some artificial sequestration techniques exploit these natural processes,<ref name=glossary/> while some use entirely artificial processes.
There are three ways that this sequestration can be carried out; post-combustion capture, pre-combustion capture, and oxy-combustion. A wide variety of separation techniques are being pursued, including gas phase separation, absorption into a liquid, and adsorption on a solid, as well as hybrid processes, such as adsorption/membrane systems. These above processes basically will capture carbon emitting from power plants, factories, fuel burning industries and so on.
== Biological processes == [[Image:Phytoplankton SoAtlantic 20060215.jpg|right|thumb|upright|An oceanic [[Algal bloom|phytoplankton bloom]] in the [[South Atlantic Ocean]], off the coast of [[Argentina]]. Encouraging such blooms with iron fertilization could lock up carbon on the seabed.]]
[[Biosequestration]] or carbon sequestration through [[biological processes]] affects the global [[carbon cycle]]. Examples include major climatic fluctuations, such as the [[Azolla event]], which created the current [[Arctic]] climate. Such processes created [[fossil fuel]]s, as well as [[clathrate]] and [[limestone]]. By manipulating such processes, geoengineers seek to enhance sequestration.
=== Peat production === [[Peat bogs]] act as a sink for carbon due to the accumulation of partially decayed biomass that would otherwise continue to decay completely. There is a variance on how much the peatlands act as a carbon sink or carbon source that can be linked to varying climates in different areas of the world and different times of the year.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Strack|first1=ed. by Maria|title=Peatlands and climate change|date=2008|publisher=University of Calgary|location=Calgary|isbn=978-952-99401-1-0|pages=13–23|url=http://www.peatsociety.org/peatlands-and-peat/peatlands-and-climate-change|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> By creating new bogs, or enhancing existing ones, the amount of carbon that is sequestered by bogs would increase.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19826542.400-burying-biomass-to-fight-climate-change.html |title=Burying biomass to fight climate change |journal=New Scientist |issue=2654 |date=May 3, 2008 |first=Richard |last=Lovett |subscription=yes |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref>
=== Forestry ===
[[Reforestation]] is the replanting of trees on marginal crop and [[pasture]] lands to incorporate carbon from atmospheric {{chem|CO|2}} into [[biomass]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2008/08/aerial-reforestation-explored-in-discovery-project-earth-premiere.php |title=Can Aerial Reforestation Help Slow Climate Change? Discovery Project Earth Examines Re-Engineering the Planet's Possibilities |website=TreeHugger |date=August 22, 2008 |first=Matthew |last=McDermott |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> For this process to succeed the carbon must not return to the atmosphere from mass burning or rotting when the trees die.<ref>{{cite report |title=CRS Report for Congress: Carbon Sequestration in Forests |date=March 29, 2007 |first=Ross W. |last=Gorte |publisher=Congressional Research Service |url=http://www.nationalaglawcenter.org/wp-content/uploads/assets/crs/RL31432.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=August 21, 2015}}</ref> To this end, land allotted to the trees must not be converted to other uses and management of the frequency of disturbances might be necessary in order to avoid extreme events. Alternatively, the wood from them must itself be sequestered, e.g., via [[biochar]], bio-energy with carbon storage ([[Bio-energy with carbon capture and storage|BECS]]), landfill or 'stored' by use in e.g. construction. Short of growth in perpetuity, however, reforestation with long-lived trees (>100 years) will sequester carbon for a more graduated release, minimizing impact during the expected [[carbon crisis]] of the 21st century.
====Urban Forestry==== [[Urban Forestry]] increases the amount of carbon taken up in cities by adding new tree sites and the sequestration of carbon occurs over the lifetime of the tree.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/psw/publications/mcpherson/psw_2013_mcpherson005.pdf |format=PDF |title=A new approach to quantify and map carbon stored, sequestered and emissions avoided by urban forests |last1=McPherson |first1=E. Gregory |last2=Xiao |first2=Qingfu |last3=Aguaron |first3=Elena |journal=Landscape and Urban Planning |date=December 2013 |volume=120 |pages=70–84 |doi=10.1016/j.landurbplan.2013.08.005 |access-date=August 21, 2015}}</ref> It is generally practiced and maintained on smaller scales, like in cities. The results of urban forestry can have different results depending on the type of vegetation that is being used, so it can function as a sink but can also function as a source of emissions.<ref name="Urb For">{{cite journal|last1=Velasco|first1=Erik|last2=Roth|first2=Matthias|last3=Norford|first3=Leslie|last4=Molina|first4=Luisa T.|title=Does urban vegetation enhance carbon sequestration?|journal=Landscape and Urban Planning|date=April 2016|volume=148|pages=99–107|doi=10.1016/j.landurbplan.2015.12.003}}</ref> Along with sequestration by the plants which is difficult to measure but seems to have little effect on the overall amount of carbon dioxide that is uptaken, the vegetation can have indirect effects on carbon by reducing need for energy consumption.<ref name="Urb For" />
=== Wetland restoration === Wetland soil is an important carbon sink; 14.5% of the world’s [[soil carbon]] is found in wetlands, while only 6% of the world’s land is composed of wetlands.<ref name='nelson'>{{cite web|url=http://www.puaf.umd.edu/papers/nelson/carbseq.htm |last=Nelson |first=Robert |title=Carbon Sequestration: A Better Alternative for Climate Change? |date=July 1999 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
=== Agriculture === {{See also|Carbon farming}}
Compared to natural vegetation, cropland soils are depleted in soil organic carbon (SOC). When a soil is converted from natural land or semi natural land, such as forests, woodlands, grasslands, steppes and savannas, the SOC content in the soil reduces with about 30–40%.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Poeplau|first=Christopher|last2=Don|first2=Axel|date=2015-02-01|title=Carbon sequestration in agricultural soils via cultivation of cover crops – A meta-analysis|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167880914004873|journal=Agriculture, Ecosystems & Environment|volume=200|issue=Supplement C|pages=33–41|doi=10.1016/j.agee.2014.10.024}}</ref> This loss is due to the removal of plant material containing carbon, in terms of harvests. When the land use changes, the carbon in the soil will either increase or decrease, this change will continue until the soil reaches a new equilibrium. Deviations from this equilibrium can also be affected by variated climate .<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goglio|first=Pietro|last2=Smith|first2=Ward N.|last3=Grant|first3=Brian B.|last4=Desjardins|first4=Raymond L.|last5=McConkey|first5=Brian G.|last6=Campbell|first6=Con A.|last7=Nemecek|first7=Thomas|date=2015-10-01|title=Accounting for soil carbon changes in agricultural life cycle assessment (LCA): a review|url=https://www.deepdyve.com/lp/elsevier/accounting-for-soil-carbon-changes-in-agricultural-life-cycle-7fKGPeVfUr|journal=Journal of Cleaner Production|language=en|volume=104|pages=23–39|doi=10.1016/j.jclepro.2015.05.040|issn=0959-6526}}</ref> The decreasing of SOC content can be counteracted by increasing the carbon input, this can be done with several strategies, e.g. leave harvest residues on the field, use manure as fertiliser or include perennial crops in the rotation. Perennial crops have larger below ground biomass fraction, which increases the SOC content.<ref name=":3" /> Globally, soils are estimated to contain approximately 1,500 gigatons of organic carbon to 1 m depth, more than the amount in vegetation and the atmosphere.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Batjes |first=Niels H. |journal=European Journal of Soil Science |volume=47 |issue=2 |pages=151–163 |title=Total carbon and nitrogen in the soils of the world |date=June 1996 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2389.1996.tb01386.x }}</ref><ref name="Smith">{{cite book |first=Pete |last=Smith |chapter=Soil Organic Carbon Dynamics and Land-Use Change |editor1-first=Ademola K. |editor1-last=Braimoh |editor2-first=Paul L.G. |editor2-last=Vlek |title=Land Use and Soil Resources |chapter-url={{google books|uV7Jp9Iz1hsC|plainurl=yes|page=9}} |publisher=Springer |location=Stockholm, Sweden |date=2007 |isbn=978-1-4020-6777-8 |lccn=2007941782 |access-date=August 21, 2015}}</ref>
Modification of agricultural practices is a recognized method of carbon sequestration as soil can act as an effective carbon sink offsetting as much as 20% of 2010 carbon dioxide emissions annually.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/21/opinion/iowas-climate-change-wisdom.html?action%3Dclick%26pgtype%3DHomepage%26clickSource%3Dstory-heading%26module%3Dopinion-c-col-right-region%26region%3Dopinion-c-col-right-region%26WT.nav%3Dopinion-c-col-right-region%26_r%3D0 |title=Iowa’s Climate-Change Wisdom |newspaper=New York Times |accessdate=2015-11-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123211510/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/21/opinion/iowas-climate-change-wisdom.html?action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=opinion-c-col-right-region&region=opinion-c-col-right-region&WT.nav=opinion-c-col-right-region&_r=0 |archivedate=November 23, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref> (See [[No-till]])
Carbon emission reduction methods in agriculture can be grouped into two categories: reducing and/or displacing emissions and enhancing carbon removal. Some of these reductions involve increasing the efficiency of farm operations (e.g. more fuel-efficient equipment) while some involve interruptions in the natural carbon cycle. Also, some effective techniques (such as the elimination of [[stubble burning]]) can negatively impact other environmental concerns (increased herbicide use to control weeds not destroyed by burning).
=== Deep Soil ===
Soils hold four times the amount of carbon stored in the atmosphere.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tarnocai|first=C.|last2=Canadell|first2=J.G.|last3=Schuur|first3=E.A.G.|last4=Kuhry|first4=P.|last5=Mazhitova|first5=G.|last6=Zimov|first6=S.|date=2009-06-01|title=Soil organic carbon pools in the northern circumpolar permafrost region|journal=Global Biogeochemical Cycles|language=en|volume=23|issue=2|pages=GB2023|doi=10.1029/2008gb003327|issn=1944-9224|bibcode=2009GBioC..23.2023T}}</ref> About half of this is found deep within soils.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schmidt, Torn, Abiven, Dittmar, Guggenberger, Janssens, Kleber, Kogel-Knabner, Lehmann, Manning, Nannipieri, Rasse, Weiner, Trumbore|first=M.W.I., M.S., S., T., G., I.A., M., I., J., D.A.C., P., D.P., S., S.E.|date=2011|title=Persistence of soil organic matter as an ecosystem property|url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc844476/m2/1/high_res_d/1051632.pdf|journal=Nature|volume=478|issue=7367|pages=49–56|via=|doi=10.1038/nature10386|pmid=21979045|bibcode=2011Natur.478...49S|type=Submitted manuscript}}</ref> About 90% of this deep soil C is stabilized by mineral-organic associations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Advances in Agronomy Chapter 1 Mineral - Organic Associations : Formation, Properties, and Relevance in Soil Environments|last=Kleber, Eusterhues, Keiluweit, Mikutta, Mikutta, S. Nico.|first=Markus, Karin, Marco, Christian, Robert, Peter|publisher=Academic Press|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=Chapter 1, 1–140}}</ref>
==== Reducing emissions ==== Increasing yields and efficiency generally reduces emissions as well, since more food results from the same or less effort. Techniques include more accurate use of [[fertilizer]]s, less soil disturbance, better [[irrigation]], and crop strains bred for locally beneficial traits and increased yields.
Replacing more energy [[intensive farming]] operations can also reduce emissions. Reduced or [[no-till farming]] requires less machine use and burns correspondingly less fuel per acre. However, no-till usually increases use of weed-control chemicals and the residue now left on the soil surface is more likely to release its {{chem|CO|2}} to the atmosphere as it decays, reducing the net carbon reduction.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
In practice, most farming operations that incorporate post-harvest crop residues, wastes and byproducts back into the soil provide a carbon storage benefit.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} This is particularly the case for practices such as field burning of stubble – rather than releasing almost all of the stored {{chem|CO|2}} to the atmosphere, tillage incorporates the biomass back into the soil.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
==== Enhancing carbon removal ==== All crops absorb {{chem|CO|2}} during growth and release it after harvest. The goal of agricultural carbon removal is to use the crop and its relation to the carbon cycle to permanently sequester carbon within the soil. This is done by selecting farming methods that return biomass to the soil and enhance the conditions in which the carbon within the plants will be reduced to its elemental nature and stored in a stable state. Methods for accomplishing this include: * Use [[cover crop]]s such as grasses and weeds as temporary cover between planting seasons * Concentrate livestock in small paddocks for days at a time so they graze lightly but evenly. This encourages roots to grow deeper into the soil. Stock also till the soil with their hooves, grinding old grass and manures into the soil.<ref name=australia>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/environmentNews/idUSTRE55G01B20090617?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=FACTBOX: Carbon farming on rise in Australia |work=Reuters |date=June 16, 2009 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> * Cover bare paddocks with hay or dead vegetation. This protects soil from the sun and allows the soil to hold more water and be more attractive to carbon-capturing microbes.<ref name=australia/> * Restore degraded land, which slows carbon release while returning the land to agriculture or other use.
Agricultural sequestration practices may have positive effects on [[soil]], air, and water quality, be beneficial to [[wildlife]], and expand [[food production]]. On degraded [[croplands]], an increase of 1 ton of soil carbon pool may increase crop yield by 20 to 40 kilograms per hectare of [[wheat]], 10 to 20 kg/ ha for maize, and 0.5 to 1 kg/ha for [[cowpeas]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}}
The effects of soil sequestration can be reversed. If the soil is disrupted or tillage practices are abandoned, the soil becomes a net source of greenhouse gases. Typically after 15 to 30 years of sequestration, soil becomes saturated and ceases to absorb carbon. This implies that there is a global limit to the amount of carbon that soil can hold.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sundermeiera |first1=A.P. |last2=Islam |first2=K.R. |last3=Raut |first3=Y. |last4=Reeder |first4=R.C. |last5=Dick |first5=W.A. |title=Continuous No-Till Impacts on Soil Biophysical Carbon Sequestration |journal=Soil Science Society of America Journal |volume=75 |issue=5 |pages=1779–1788 |date=September 2010 |doi=10.2136/sssaj2010.0334 |url=https://www.soils.org/publications/sssaj/abstracts/75/5/1779 |access-date=August 21, 2015|bibcode=2011SSASJ..75.1779S }}</ref>
Many factors affect the costs of carbon sequestration including soil quality, transaction costs and various externalities such as leakage and unforeseen environmental damage. Because reduction of atmospheric {{chem|CO|2}} is a long-term concern, farmers can be reluctant to adopt more expensive agricultural techniques when there is not a clear crop, soil, or economic benefit. Governments such as Australia and New Zealand are considering allowing farmers to sell carbon credits once they document that they have sufficiently increased soil carbon content.<ref name=australia/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Smith |first1=Pete |last2=Martino |first2=Daniel |last3=Cai |first3=Zucong |title=Greenhouse gas mitigation in agriculture |journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B]] |volume=363 |issue=1492 |pages=789–813 |date=February 2008 |pmid=17827109 |pmc=2610110 |doi=10.1098/rstb.2007.2184 |url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17827109 |display-authors=etal}}.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Environmental Co Benefits of Sequestration Practices. 2006. June 1, 2009. |url=http://www.epa.gov/sequestration/co-benefits.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511195852/http://www.epa.gov/sequestration/co-benefits.html |archivedate=May 11, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Lal |first=R. |title=Soil Carbon Sequestration Impacts on Global Climate Change and Food Security |journal=Science |volume=304 |issue=5677 |date=June 11, 2004 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/304/5677/1623 |pmid=15192216 |doi=10.1126/science.1097396 |pages=1623–1627|bibcode = 2004Sci...304.1623L |subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Addressing Reversibility (Duration) for Projects |publisher=US Environmental Protection Agency. 2006. June 1, 2009 |url=http://www.epa.gov/sequestration/duration.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013103758/http://www.epa.gov/sequestration/duration.html |archivedate=October 13, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Renwick |first1=A. |last2=Ball |first2=A. |last3=Pretty |first3=J.N. |title=Biological and Policy Constraints on the Adoption of Carbon Farming in Temperate Regions |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A |volume=360 |issue=1797 |pages=1721–40 |date=August 2002 |pmid=12460494 |doi=10.1098/rsta.2002.1028 |url=http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/360/1797/1721.abstract?sid=781c4abf-2514-48a1-b4a2-47856b3aa08b|bibcode = 2002RSPTA.360.1721R }} pp. 1722, 1726—29.</ref>
=== Ocean-related ===
==== Iron fertilization ==== {{Main|Iron fertilization}}
Ocean iron fertilization is an example of such a geoengineering technique.<ref name="spiegel.de">{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,599213,00.html#ref=rss |title=Cold Carbon Sink: Slowing Global Warming with Antarctic Iron |first=Gerald |last=Traufetter |work=Spiegel Online |date=January 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> Iron fertilization<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.biogeosciences.net/5/385/2008/bg-5-385-2008.html |title=The impact on atmospheric {{chem|CO|2}} of iron fertilization induced changes in the ocean's biological pump |journal=Biogeosciences |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=385–406 |year=2008 |first1=X. |last1=Jin |first2=N. |last2=Gruber |first3=H. |last3=Frenzel1 |first4=S.C. |last4=Doney |first5=J.C. |last5=McWilliams |doi=10.5194/bg-5-385-2008 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> attempts to encourage [[Algal bloom|phytoplankton growth]], which removes carbon from the atmosphere for at least a period of time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-formal.stanford.edu/pub/jmc/progress/iron/iron.html |title=Iron versus the Greenhouse - Oceanographers cautiously explore a global warming therapy |first=Richard |last=Monastersky |publisher=Science News |date=September 30, 1995 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Iron versus the Greenhouse: Oceanographers cautiously explore a global warming therapy |journal=Science News |last=Monastersky |first=Richard |date=September 30, 1995 |url=https://www.sciencenews.org/archive/iron-versus-greenhouse |volume=148 |issue=14 |pages=220–222 |subscription=yes |access-date=August 21, 2015 |doi=10.2307/4018225|jstor=4018225 }}</ref> This technique is controversial due to limited understanding of its complete effects on the marine [[ecosystem]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.geoengineeringmonitor.org/2007/06/wwf-condemns-planktos-inc-iron-seeding-plan-in-the-galapagos/ |title=WWF condemns Planktos Inc. iron-seeding plan in the Galapagos |work=Geoengineering Monitor |date=June 27, 2007|accessdate=August 21, 2015}}</ref> including side effects and possibly large deviations from expected behavior. Such effects potentially include release of [[nitrogen oxide]]s,<ref name="alertnet.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/SP39844.htm |title=Scientists urge caution in ocean-{{chem|CO|2}} capture schemes |publisher=Alertnet.org |date=December 15, 2008 |first=David |last=Fogarty |accessdate=May 9, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090803085453/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/SP39844.htm |archivedate=August 3, 2009 |df=mdy }}</ref> and disruption of the ocean's nutrient balance.<ref name="spiegel.de" />
Natural iron fertilisation events (e.g., deposition of iron-rich dust into ocean waters) can enhance carbon sequestration. Sperm whales act as agents of iron fertilisation when they transport iron from the deep ocean to the surface during prey consumption and defecation. Sperm whales have been shown to increase the levels of primary production and carbon export to the deep ocean by depositing iron rich feces into surface waters of the Southern Ocean. The iron rich feces causes phytoplankton to grow and take up more carbon from the atmosphere. When the phytoplankton dies, some of it sinks to the deep ocean and takes the atmospheric carbon with it. By reducing the abundance of sperm whales in the Southern Ocean, whaling has resulted in an extra 200,000 tonnes of carbon remaining in the atmosphere each year.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lavery |first1=Trish J. |last2=Roudnew |first2=Ben |last3=Gill |first3=Peter |date=October 11, 2010 |title=Iron defecation by sperm whales stimulates carbon export in the Southern Ocean |url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/277/1699/3527 |journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]] |volume=277 |issue=1699 |pages=3527–3531 |doi=10.1098/rspb.2010.0863 |pmid=20554546 |pmc=2982231 |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==== Urea fertilization ==== {{Main|Ocean nourishment}}
[[Ian Jones (scientist)|Ian Jones]] proposes fertilizing the ocean with [[urea]], a [[nitrogen]] rich substance, to encourage [[phytoplankton]] growth.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/6369401.stm|title=Multiplying the ocean's CO2 guzzlers|date=February 19, 2007|publisher=|via=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
Australian company Ocean Nourishment Corporation (ONC) plans to sink hundreds of tonnes of urea into the ocean to boost {{chem|CO|2}}-absorbing phytoplankton growth as a way to combat climate change. In 2007, Sydney-based ONC completed an experiment involving 1 tonne of nitrogen in the Sulu Sea off the Philippines.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/science/articles/2007/11/09/2085584.htm |title=Urea 'climate solution' may backfire |work=ABC Science |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Commission |first=Anna |last=Salleh |date=November 9, 2007 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref>
==== Mixing layers ==== Encouraging various ocean layers to mix can move nutrients and dissolved gases around, offering avenues for [[climate engineering|geoengineering]].<ref name=Lovelock07/> Mixing may be achieved by placing large vertical pipes in the oceans to pump nutrient rich water to the surface, triggering [[algal blooms|blooms of algae]], which store carbon when they grow and export carbon when they die.<ref name=Lovelock07>{{cite journal |last1=Lovelock |first1=James E. |last2=Rapley |first2=Chris G. |authorlink2=Chris Rapley |title=Ocean pipes could help the earth to cure itself |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v449/n7161/full/449403a.html |journal=Nature |volume=449 |issue=7161 |page=403 |date=September 27, 2007 |pmid=17898747 |doi=10.1038/449403a |bibcode=2007Natur.449..403L |subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn12698 |title=Ocean pumps could counter global warming |journal=New Scientist |date=September 26, 2007 |first=Fred |last=Pearce |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=A proposal to force vertical mixing of the Pacific Equatorial Undercurrent to create a system of equatorially trapped coupled convection that counteracts global warming |url=http://www.johnduke.com/JDukeETCC09052007.pdf |format=PDF |journal=Geophysical Research Abstracts |year=2008 |last=Duke |first=John H. |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> This produces results somewhat similar to iron fertilization. One side-effect is a short-term rise in {{chem|CO|2}}, which limits its attractiveness.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Impact of enhanced vertical mixing on marine biogeochemistry: lessons for geo-engineering and natural variability |url=http://www.biogeosciences.net/6/901/2009/bg-6-901-2009.html |last1=Dutreuil |first1=S. |last2=Bopp |first2=L. |last3=Tagliabue |first3=A. |journal=Biogeosciences |date=May 25, 2009 |volume=6 |issue=5 |pages=901–912 |doi=10.5194/bg-6-901-2009 |access-date=August 21, 2015}}</ref>
==== Seaweed ==== [[Seaweed]] grows very fast and can theoretically be harvested and processed to generate [[biomethane]], via [[Anaerobic Digestion]] to generate electricity, via [[Cogeneration|Cogeneration/CHP]] or as a replacement for [[natural gas]]. One study suggested that if seaweed farms covered 9% of the ocean they could produce enough biomethane to supply Earth's equivalent demand for fossil fuel energy, remove 53 [[gigatonnes]] of {{CO2|link=yes}} per year from the atmosphere and sustainably produce 200 kg per year of fish, per person, for 10 billion people.<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[Tim Flannery|Flannery]]|first1=Tim|title=Climate crisis: seaweed, coffee and cement could save the planet|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/nov/20/climate-crisis-future-brighter-tim-flannery|accessdate=25 November 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=20 November 2015}}</ref> Ideal species for such farming and conversion include ''[[Laminaria digitata]]'', ''[[Fucus serratus]]'' and ''[[Saccharina latissima]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vanegasa|first1=C. H.|last2=Bartletta|first2=J.|title=Green energy from marine algae: biogas production and composition from the anaerobic digestion of Irish seaweed species|journal=Environmental Technology|date=11 Feb 2013|volume=34|issue=15|pages=2277–2283|doi=10.1080/09593330.2013.765922|pmid=24350482}}<!--|accessdate=25 November 2015--></ref>
== Physical processes == [[Image:Charcoal2.jpg|right|thumb|[[Biochar]] can be landfilled, used as a [[soil improver]] or burned using [[carbon capture and storage]]]]
=== Biomass-related ===
==== Bio-energy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) ==== {{Main|Bio-energy with carbon capture and storage}} BECCS refers to biomass in [[power stations]] and [[boilers]] that use carbon capture and storage.<ref>{{cite report |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg3/ar4-wg3-chapter3.pdf |format=PDF |chapter=Issues related to mitigation in the long term context, In Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. |last1=Fisher |first1=Brian |last2=Nakicenovic |first2=Nebojsa |year=2007 |title=Fourth Assessment Report of the Inter-governmental Panel on Climate Change |publisher= Cambridge University Press |display-authors=etal |access-date=August 21, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.294.5543.786b |last1=Obersteiner |first1=M. |first2=Christian |last2=Azar |first3=P. |last3=Kauppi |display-authors=etal |title=Managing climate risk |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/294/5543/786.2 |journal=Science |volume=294 |issue=5543 |pages=786–87 |date=October 26, 2001 |pmid=11681318 |subscription=yes}}</ref> The carbon sequestered by the biomass would be captured and stored, thus removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10584-005-3484-7 |first1=Christian |last1=Azar |title=Carbon Capture and Storage From Fossil Fuels and Biomass – Costs and Potential Role in Stabilizing the Atmosphere |journal=Climatic Change |volume=74 |issue=1–3 |pages=47–79 |date=January 2006 |display-authors=etal }}</ref>
This technology is sometimes referred to as [[bio-energy with carbon capture and storage|bio-energy with carbon storage]], BECS, though this term can also refer to the carbon sequestration potential in other technologies, such as biochar.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
==== Burial ==== Burying biomass (such as trees)<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1750-0680-3-1 |url=http://www.cbmjournal.com/content/3/1/1 |pmc=2266747 |title=Carbon sequestration via wood burial |first=Ning |last=Zeng |pmid=18173850 |journal=Carbon Balance and Management |year=2008 |volume=3 |issue=1 |page=1}}</ref> directly, mimics the natural processes that created [[fossil fuels]].<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19826542.400 |title=Burying biomass to fight climate change |first=Richard |last=Lovett |issue=2654 |journal=New Scientist |date=May 3, 2008 |accessdate=May 9, 2010 |subscription=yes}}</ref> [[Landfills]] also represent a physical method of sequestration.
==== Biochar burial ==== {{Main|Biochar}} [[Biochar]] is [[charcoal]] created by [[pyrolysis]] of [[biomass]] waste. The resulting material is added to a [[landfill]] or used as a soil improver to create [[terra preta]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Lehmann, J. |author2=Gaunt, J. |author3=Rondon, M. |title=Bio-char sequestration in terrestrial ecosystems – a review |journal=Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies for Global Change |volume=11|issue=2 |pages=403–427 |year=2006 |doi=10.1007/s11027-005-9006-5|url=http://www.css.cornell.edu/faculty/lehmann/publ/MitAdaptStratGlobChange%2011%2C%20403-427%2C%20Lehmann%2C%202006.pdf |type=Submitted manuscript |citeseerx=10.1.1.183.1147 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biochar-international.org/|title=International Biochar Initiative | International Biochar Initiative|publisher=Biochar-international.org |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> Addition of pyrogenic organic carbon (biochar) is a novel strategy to increase the soil-C stock for the long-term and to mitigate global-warming by offsetting the atmospheric C (up to 9.5 Pg C annually).<ref>Balal Yousaf, Guijian Liu, Ruwei Wang, Qumber Abbas, Muhammad Imtiaz, Ruijia Liu: Investigating the biochar effects on C-mineralization and sequestration of carbon in soil compared with conventional amendments using stable isotope (δ13C) approach. GCB Bioenergy 2016; {{DOI|10.1111/gcbb.12401}}</ref>
In the soil, the carbon is unavailable for [[oxidation]] to {{chem|CO|2}} and consequential atmospheric release. This is one technique advocated by [[scientist]] [[James Lovelock]], creator of the [[Gaia hypothesis]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20126921.500-one-last-chance-to-save-mankind.html?full=true |title=One last chance to save mankind |author=Gaia Vince |journal=New Scientist |date=January 23, 2009|accessdate=May 9, 2010}}{{Subscription#doc editlinks|date=May 2010}}</ref> According to Simon Shackley, "people are talking more about something in the range of one to two billion tonnes a year."<ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/67843ec0-020b-11de-8199-000077b07658.html | title= Black is the new green | last= Harvey | first= Fiona |date= February 27, 2009 | work= [[Financial Times]] |publisher= | accessdate= March 4, 2009 }}</ref>
The mechanisms related to biochar are referred to as [[bio-energy with carbon capture and storage|bio-energy with carbon storage]], BECS.
=== Ocean storage === If CO<sub>2</sub> were to be injected to the ocean bottom, the pressures would be great enough for CO<sub>2</sub> to be in its liquid phase. The idea behind ocean injection would be to have stable, stationary pools of CO<sub>2</sub> at the ocean floor. The ocean could potentially hold over a thousand billion tons of CO<sub>2</sub>. However, this avenue of sequestration isn’t being as actively pursued because of concerns about the impact on ocean life, and concerns about its stability.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Benson|first=S.M.|last2=Surles|first2=T.|date=2006-10-01|title=Carbon Dioxide Capture and Storage: An Overview With Emphasis on Capture and Storage in Deep Geological Formations|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/lpdocs/epic03/wrapper.htm?arnumber=4016413|journal=Proceedings of the IEEE|volume=94|issue=10|pages=1795–1805|doi=10.1109/JPROC.2006.883718|issn=0018-9219}}</ref>
River mouths bring large quantities of nutrients and dead material from upriver into the ocean as part of the process that eventually produces fossil fuels. Transporting material such as crop waste out to sea and allowing it to sink exploits this idea to increase carbon storage.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/es8015556 |title=Ocean Sequestration of Crop Residue Carbon: Recycling Fossil Fuel Carbon Back to Deep Sediments |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |first2=Gregory |last2=Benford |volume=43 |author=Stuart E. Strand |pages=1000–1007 |date=January 12, 2009 |issue=4 |bibcode = 2009EnST...43.1000S }}</ref> International regulations on [[marine dumping]] may restrict or prevent use of this technique.
=== Geological sequestration === {{Main|Carbon capture and storage}}
Geological sequestration refers to the storage of CO<sub>2</sub> underground in depleted oil and gas reservoirs, saline formations, or deep, un-minable coal beds.
Once CO<sub>2</sub> is captured from a gas or coal-fired power plant, it would be compressed to ≈100 bar so that it would be a supercritical fluid. In this fluid form, the CO<sub>2</sub> would be easy to transport via pipeline to the place of storage. The CO<sub>2</sub> would then be injected deep underground, typically around 1 km, where it would be stable for hundreds to millions of years.<ref name=":0" /> At these storage conditions, the density of supercritical CO<sub>2</sub> is 600 to 800 kg / m<sup>3</sup>.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Aydin|first=Gokhan|last2=Karakurt|first2=Izzet|last3=Aydiner|first3=Kerim|date=2010-09-01|title=Evaluation of geologic storage options of CO2: Applicability, cost, storage capacity and safety|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421510003095|journal=Energy Policy|series=Special Section on Carbon Emissions and Carbon Management in Cities with Regular Papers|volume=38|issue=9|pages=5072–5080|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2010.04.035}}</ref> For consumers, the cost of electricity from a coal-fired power plant with carbon capture and storage (CCS) is estimated to be 0.01–0.05 $ / kWh higher than without CCS. For reference, the average cost of electricity in the US in 2004 was 0.0762 $ / kWh. In other terms, the cost of CCS would be 20–70 $/ton of CO<sub>2</sub> captured. The transportation and injection of CO<sub>2</sub> is relatively cheap, with the capture costs accounting for 70–80% of CCS costs.<ref name=":1" />
The important parameters in determining a good site for carbon storage are: rock porosity, rock permeability, absence of faults, and geometry of rock layers. The medium in which the CO<sub>2</sub> is to be stored ideally has a high porosity and permeability, such as sandstone or limestone. Sandstone can have a permeability ranging from 1 to 10<sup>−5</sup> Darcy, and can have a porosity as high as ≈30%. The porous rock must be capped by a layer of low permeability which acts as a seal, or caprock, for the CO<sub>2</sub>. Shale is an example of a very good caprock, with a permeability of 10<sup>−5</sup> to 10<sup>−9</sup> Darcy. Once injected, the CO<sub>2</sub> plume will rise via buoyant forces, since it is less dense than its surroundings. Once it encounters a caprock, it will spread laterally until it encounters a gap. If there are fault planes near the injection zone, there is a possibility the CO<sub>2</sub> could migrate along the fault to the surface, leaking into the atmosphere, which would be potentially dangerous to life in the surrounding area. Another danger related to carbon sequestration is induced seismicity. If the injection of CO<sub>2</sub> creates pressures that are too high underground, the formation will fracture, causing an earthquake.<ref name=":2">Smit, Berend; Reimer, Jeffrey A.; Oldenburg, Curtis M.; Bourg, Ian C. (2014). ''Introduction to Carbon Capture and Sequestration''. London: Imperial College Press. {{ISBN|978-1783263288}}.</ref>
While trapped in a rock formation, CO<sub>2</sub> can be in the supercritical fluid phase or dissolve in groundwater/brine. It can also react with minerals in the geologic formation to precipitate carbonates. See [[CarbFix]].
Worldwide storage capacity in oil and gas reservoirs is estimated to be 675–900 Gt CO<sub>2</sub>, and in un-minable coal seams is estimated to be 15–200 Gt CO<sub>2</sub>. Deep saline formations have the largest capacity, which is estimated to be 1,000–10,000 Gt CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref name=":1" /> In the US, there is an estimated 160 Gt CO<sub>2</sub> storage capacity.<ref name=":2" />
There are a number of large-scale carbon capture and sequestration projects that have demonstrated the viability and safety of this method of carbon storage, which are summarized here <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalccsinstitute.com/projects/large-scale-ccs-projects#overview|title=Large-scale CCS facilities |publisher= Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute|website=www.globalccsinstitute.com}}</ref> by the Global CCS Institute. The dominant monitoring technique is seismic imaging, where vibrations are generated that propagate through the subsurface. The geologic structure can be imaged from the refracted/reflected waves.<ref name=":2" />
The first large-scale {{chem|CO|2}} sequestration project which began in 1996 is called [[Sleipner gas field|Sleipner]], and is located in the [[North Sea]] where Norway's [[StatoilHydro]] strips carbon dioxide from [[natural gas]] with [[amine]] [[solvent]]s and disposed of this carbon dioxide in a deep [[saline water|saline]] [[aquifer]]. In 2000, a coal-fueled [[synthetic natural gas]] plant in [[Beulah, North Dakota]], became the world's first coal-using plant to capture and store carbon dioxide, at the [[Weyburn-Midale Carbon Dioxide Project]].<ref>{{cite web | title= Weyburn-Midale {{chem|CO|2}} Project, World's first {{chem|CO|2}} measuring, monitoring and verification initiative | url=http://www.ptrc.ca/weyburn_overview.php | publisher= Petroleum Technology Research Centre| accessdate=April 9, 2009}}</ref>
{{chem|CO|2}} has been used extensively in enhanced [[crude oil]] recovery operations in the [[United States]] beginning in 1972.<ref name=Hodrien/> There are in excess of 10,000 wells that inject {{chem|CO|2}} in the state of [[Texas]] alone. The gas comes in part from anthropogenic sources, but is principally from large naturally occurring geologic formations of {{chem|CO|2}}. It is transported to the oil-producing fields through a large network of over {{convert|5000|km}} of {{chem|CO|2}} pipelines. The use of {{chem|CO|2}} for [[enhanced oil recovery]] (EOR) methods in heavy oil reservoirs in the [[Western Canadian Sedimentary Basin]] (WCSB) has also been proposed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyoilbulletin.com/issues/article.asp?article=dob%2F080415%2FDOB2008%5FAF0019%2Ehtml |title=Subscription Verification |publisher=Dailyoilbulletin.com |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}{{dead link|date=January 2017}}</ref> However, transport cost remains an important hurdle. An extensive {{chem|CO|2}} pipeline system does not yet exist in the WCSB. [[Athabasca oil sands]] mining that produces {{chem|CO|2}} is hundreds of kilometers north of the subsurface [[Heavy crude oil]] reservoirs that could most benefit from {{chem|CO|2}} injection.
== Chemical processes == Developed in the Netherlands, an electrocatalysis by a copper complex helps [[carbon fixation|reduce carbon dioxide]] to [[oxalic acid]];<ref name=Bouwman>{{cite journal |last1=Bouwman |first1=Elisabeth |last2=Angamuthu |first2=Raja |last3=Byers |first3=Philip |last4=Lutz |first4=Martin |last5=Spek |first5=Anthony L. |title=Electrocatalytic CO2 Conversion to Oxalate by a Copper Complex |journal=Science |date=July 15, 2010 |volume=327 |issue=5393 |pages=313–315 |doi=10.1126/science.1177981|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/327/5963/313|accessdate=26 September 2014|bibcode = 2010Sci...327..313A |pmid=20075248|citeseerx=10.1.1.1009.2076 }}</ref> This conversion [[carbon capture and storage|uses carbon dioxide as a feedstock]] to generate oxalic acid.
=== Mineral carbonation === Carbon, in the form of {{chem|CO|2}} can be removed from the atmosphere by chemical processes, and stored in stable [[carbonate mineral]] forms. This process is known as 'carbon sequestration by mineral [[carbonation]]' or mineral sequestration. The process involves reacting carbon dioxide with abundantly available metal oxides–either [[magnesium oxide]] (MgO) or [[calcium oxide]] (CaO)–to form stable carbonates. These reactions are [[exothermic]] and occur naturally (e.g., the [[weathering]] of rock over [[geologic time]] periods).<ref name=herzog/><ref name=goldberg>{{Cite journal | last = Goldberg | first = Philip |author2=Zhong-Ying Chen |author3=O'Connor, William |author4=Walters, Richard |author5=Ziock Hans | title ={{chem|CO|2}} Mineral Sequestration Studies in US | publisher = National Energy Technology Laboratory | year = 1998 | url= http://www.netl.doe.gov/publications/proceedings/01/carbon_seq/6c1.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =March 6, 2009}} </ref>
:CaO + {{chem|CO|2}} → {{chem|CaCO|3}}
:MgO + {{chem|CO|2}} → {{chem|MgCO|3}}
Calcium and magnesium are found in nature typically as calcium and magnesium [[silicate minerals|silicates]] (such as [[forsterite]] and [[serpentinite]]) and not as binary oxides. For forsterite and serpentine the reactions are: :{{chem|Mg|2|SiO|4}} + 2 {{chem|CO|2}} → 2 {{chem|MgCO|3}} + {{chem|SiO|2}}
:{{chem|Mg|3|Si|2|O|5|(OH)|4}}+ 3 {{chem|CO|2}} → 3 {{chem|MgCO|3}} + 2 {{chem|SiO|2}} + 2 {{chem|H|2|O}}
The following table lists principal metal oxides of [[Crust (geology)|Earth's crust]]. Theoretically up to 22% of this mineral mass is able to form [[carbonate]]s.
{|class="wikitable" |- !Earthen Oxide!!Percent of Crust!!Carbonate!![[Standard enthalpy change of reaction|Enthalpy change]]<br />(kJ/mol) |- |{{chem|SiO|2}} |59.71 | | |- |{{chem|Al|2|O|3}} |15.41 | | |- |CaO |4.90 |[[Calcium carbonate|{{chem|CaCO|3}}]] | −179 |- |MgO |4.36 |[[Magnesium carbonate|{{chem|MgCO|3}}]] | −117 |- |{{chem|Na|2|O}} |3.55 |[[Sodium carbonate|{{chem|Na|2|CO|3}}]] | |- |FeO |3.52 |[[Iron carbonate|{{chem|FeCO|3}}]] | |- |{{chem|K|2|O}} |2.80 |[[Potassium carbonate|{{chem|K|2|CO|3}}]] | |- |{{chem|Fe|2|O|3}} |2.63 |[[Iron carbonate|{{chem|FeCO|3}}]] | |- | |21.76 |All Carbonates |}
These reactions are slightly more favorable at low temperatures.<ref name=herzog>{{cite journal |url= http://sequestration.mit.edu/pdf/carbonates.pdf |title= Carbon Sequestration via Mineral Carbonation: Overview and Assessment |last=Herzog |first=Howard |date=March 14, 2002 |publisher= Massachusetts Institute of Technology |format=PDF |accessdate=March 5, 2009}} </ref> This process occurs naturally over geologic time frames and is responsible for much of the Earth's surface [[limestone]]. The reaction rate can be made faster however, by reacting at higher temperatures and/or pressures, although this method requires some additional energy. Alternatively, the mineral could be milled to increase its surface area, and exposed to water and constant abrasion to remove the inert Silica as could be achieved naturally by dumping Olivine in the high energy surf of beaches.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Earth Syst. Dynam. Discuss.|pages=551–568|volume=2|issue=2|date=2011|author1= Schuiling, R.D.|author2=Boer, de P.L.|title = Rolling stones; fast weathering of olivine in shallow seas for cost-effective CO2 capture and mitigation of global warming and ocean acidification|url=http://www.earth-syst-dynam-discuss.net/2/551/2011/esdd-2-551-2011.pdf|doi=10.5194/esdd-2-551-2011|bibcode=2011ESDD....2..551S}}</ref> Experiments suggest the weathering process is reasonably quick (one year) given porous basaltic rocks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Yirka|first=Bob|title=Researchers find carbon reactions with basalt can form carbonate minerals faster than thought|url=http://phys.org/news/2014-04-carbon-reactions-basalt-carbonate-minerals.html|work=[[Phys.org]]|publisher=Omicron Technology Ltd|accessdate=25 April 2014}}</ref><ref name=Matter>{{cite journal |last1=Matter |first1=Juerg M. |last2=Stute |first2=Martin |last3=Snæbjörnsdottir |first3=Sandra O. |last4=Oelkers |first4=Eric H. |last5=Gislason|first5=Sigurdur R. |last6=Aradottir|first6=Edda S.|last7=Sigfusson|first7=Bergur|last8=Gunnarsson|first8=Ingvi|last9=Sigurdardottir|first9=Holmfridur|last10=Gunlaugsson|first10=Einar|last11=Axelsson|first11=Gudni|last12=Alfredsson|first12=Helgi A.|last13=Wolff-Boenisch|first13=Domenik|last14=Mesfin|first14=Kiflom|last15=Fernandez de la Reguera Taya|first15=Diana|last16=Hall|first16=Jennifer|last17=Dideriksen|first17=Knud|last18=Broecker|first18=Wallace S.|title=Rapid carbon mineralization for permanent disposal of anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions |journal=Science |date=June 10, 2016 |volume=352 |issue=6291 |pages=1312–1314 |doi=10.1126/science.aad8132|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/352/6291/1312|accessdate=10 June 2016 |pmid=27284192|bibcode=2016Sci...352.1312M}}</ref>
{{chem|CO|2}} naturally reacts with [[peridotite]] rock in surface exposures of [[ophiolite]]s, notably in [[Oman]]. It has been suggested that this process can be enhanced to carry out natural [[Mineralization (geology)|mineralisation]] of {{chem|CO|2}}.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.0805794105 |author=Peter B. Kelemen1 and Jürg Matter |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/105/45/17295.full |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA |title=In situ carbonation of peridotite for {{chem|CO|2}} storage |volume=105 |issue=45 |pages=17295–300 |date=November 3, 2008 |bibcode = 2008PNAS..10517295K |pmc=2582290 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Timothy Gardner |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/scienceNews/idUKTRE4A59IB20081107 |title=Scientists say a rock can soak up carbon dioxide | Reuters |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date= November 7, 2008|accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref>
When CO2 is dissolved in water and injected into hot basaltic rocks underground it has been shown that the CO2 reacts with the basalt to form solid carbonate minerals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2093272-co2-injected-deep-underground-turns-to-rock-and-stays-there/|title=CO<sub>2</sub> injected deep underground turns to rock – and stays there|last=Le Page|first=Michael|date=2016-06-19|work=New Scientist|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-US}}</ref> A test plant in Iceland started up in October 2017, extracting up to 50 tons of CO2 a year from the atmosphere and storing it underground in basaltic rock.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.powermag.com/test-of-carbon-capture-technology-underway-at-iceland-geothermal-plant/?mypower|title=Test of Carbon Capture Technology Underway at Iceland Geothermal Plant|last=Proctor|first=Darrell|date=2017-12-01|work=POWER Magazine|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
Researchers from [[British Columbia]], developed a low cost process for the production of [[magnesite]], also known as [[magnesium carbonate]], which can sequester CO2 from the air, or at the point of air pollution, eg. at a power plant. The crystals are naturally occurring, but accumulation is usually very slow.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90219508/this-carbon-sucking-mineral-could-help-slow-down-climate-change|title=This carbon-sucking mineral could help slow down climate change|year=2018|work=Fast Company}}</ref>
=== Industrial use === Traditional cement manufacture releases large amounts of carbon dioxide, but newly developed cement types from Novacem<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imperialinnovations.co.uk/?q=node/176 |title=Novacem |publisher=Imperial Innovations |date=May 6, 2008 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> can absorb {{chem|CO|2}} from ambient air during hardening.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/dec/31/cement-carbon-emissions | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Revealed: The cement that eats carbon dioxide| first=Alok | last=Jha | date=December 31, 2008 | accessdate=April 3, 2010}}</ref> A similar technique was pioneered by TecEco, which has been producing "EcoCement" since 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tececo.com/ |title=Home |publisher=TecEco |date=July 1, 1983 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> A Canadian startup CarbonCure takes captured CO2 and injects it into concrete as it's being mixed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/06/12/technology/concrete-carboncure/index.html|title=This concrete can trap CO2 emissions forever|last=Lord|first=Bronte|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
In Estonia, [[oil shale]] [[Bottom ash|ash]], generated by power stations could be used as [[sorbent]]s for {{chem|CO|2}} mineral sequestration. The amount of {{chem|CO|2}} captured averaged 60 to 65% of the carbonaceous {{chem|CO|2}} and 10 to 11% of the total {{chem|CO|2}} emissions.<ref name=uibu>{{Cite journal | last =Uibu | first =Mai |author2=Uus, Mati |author3=Kuusik, Rein | title ={{chem|CO|2}} mineral sequestration in oil-shale wastes from Estonian power production | journal = Journal of Environmental Management | volume = 90 | issue = 2 | pages = 1253–60 | date = February 2008 | url= https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301479708002053 | doi =10.1016/j.jenvman.2008.07.012 | pmid =18793821}} </ref>
=== Chemical scrubbers === {{Main|Carbon capture and storage|Carbon air capture}}
Various [[carbon dioxide scrubber|carbon dioxide scrubbing]] processes have been proposed to remove {{chem|CO|2}} from the air, usually using a variant of the [[Kraft process]]. Carbon dioxide scrubbing variants exist based on [[potassium carbonate]], which can be used to create liquid fuels, or on [[sodium hydroxide]].<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/19/science/19carb.html?_r=1 | work=The New York Times|title=Scientists Would Turn Greenhouse Gas Into Gasoline | first=Kenneth | last=Chang | date=February 19, 2008|accessdate=April 3, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Frank Zeman |title=Energy and Material Balance of CO<sub>2</sub> Capture from Ambient Air|journal=Environ. Sci. Technol. |volume=41 |issue=21 |pages=7558–63 |year=2007 |pmid=18044541 |doi=10.1021/es070874m|bibcode = 2007EnST...41.7558Z }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn12727 |title=Chemical 'sponge' could filter{{chem|CO|2}} from the air |date=October 3, 2007 |journal=New Scientist |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> These notably include artificial trees proposed by [[Klaus Lackner]] to remove [[carbon dioxide]] from the [[atmosphere]] using chemical [[scrubber]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livescience.com/technology/070501_carbon_capture.html |title=New Device Vacuums Away Carbon Dioxide |publisher=LiveScience |date=May 1, 2007 |accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/may/31/carbonemissions.climatechange | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Could US scientist's '{{chem|CO|2}} catcher' help to slow warming? |first=David | last=Adam | date=May 31, 2008 | accessdate=April 3, 2010}}</ref>
=== Ocean-related ===
==== Basalt storage ==== Carbon dioxide sequestration in [[basalt]] involves the injecting of {{chem|CO|2}} into deep-sea formations. The {{chem|CO|2}} first mixes with seawater and then reacts with the basalt, both of which are alkaline-rich elements. This reaction results in the release of {{chem|Ca<sup>2+</sup>}} and {{chem|Mg<sup>2+</sup>}} ions forming stable carbonate minerals.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.0804397105 |author1=David S. Goldberg |author2=Taro Takahashi |author3=Angela L. Slagle |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/105/29/9920.full |title=Carbon dioxide sequestration in deep-sea basalt|volume=105 |issue=29 |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA |pages=9920–25 |year=2008 |pmid=18626013|pmc=2464617 |bibcode = 2008PNAS..105.9920G }}</ref>
Underwater basalt offers a good alternative to other forms of oceanic carbon storage because it has a number of trapping measures to ensure added protection against leakage. These measures include “geochemical, sediment, gravitational and [[hydrate]] formation.” Because {{chem|CO|2}} hydrate is denser than {{chem|CO|2}} in seawater, the risk of leakage is minimal. Injecting the {{chem|CO|2}} at depths greater than {{convert|2700|m|ft|sp=us}} ensures that the {{chem|CO|2}} has a greater density than seawater, causing it to sink.<ref name="environmentalresearchweb.org">{{cite web|url=http://environmentalresearchweb.org/cws/article/futures/35017 |title=Carbon storage in undersea basalt offers extra security |publisher=environmentalresearchweb |date=July 15, 2008|accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref>
One possible injection site is [[Juan de Fuca plate]]. Researchers at the [[Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory]] found that this plate at the western coast of the United States has a possible storage capacity of 208 gigatons. This could cover the entire [[Greenhouse gas emissions by the United States|current U.S. carbon emissions]] for over 100 years.<ref name="environmentalresearchweb.org"/>
This process is undergoing tests as part of the [[CarbFix]] project, resulting in 95% of the injected 250 tonnes of CO2 to solidify into [[calcite]] in 2 years, using 25 tonnes of water per tonne of CO2.<ref name=Matter/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/6/10/11901368/carbon-dioxide-capture-storage-stone-climate-change-study|title=Scientists turn carbon dioxide into stone to combat global warming|date=10 June 2016|publisher=Vox Media|work=The Verge|accessdate=11 June 2016}}</ref><!--under ocean?-->

== Obstruction ==
=== Danger of leaks === Carbon dioxide may be stored deep underground. At depth, [[hydrostatic pressure]] acts to keep it in a liquid state. Reservoir design faults, rock fissures and tectonic processes may act to release the gas stored into the ocean or atmosphere.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
=== Financial costs === The use of the technology would add an additional 1–5 cents of cost per kilowatt hour, according to estimate made by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The financial costs of modern coal technology would nearly double if use of CCS technology were to be required by regulation.<ref>{{cite web |last=DeMonte |first=Adena |title=The Cost of Carbon Capture |date=July 2007 |website=Gigaom |url=https://gigaom.com/2007/07/30/the-cost-of-carbon-capture/ |access-date=August 21, 2015}}{{unreliable source? |date=August 2015 |reason=This seems to be a blog}}</ref> The cost of CCS technology differs with the different types of capture technologies being used and with the different sites that it is implemented in, but the costs tend to increase with CCS capture implementation.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gibbins|first1=Jon|last2=Chalmers|first2=Hannah|title=Carbon Capture and Storage|journal=Energy Policy|date=December 2008|volume=36|issue=12|pages=4317–4322|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2008.09.058|url=http://curryja.files.wordpress.com/2011/03/rutt_bridges_article.pdf|citeseerx=10.1.1.370.8479}}</ref> One study conducted predicted that with new technologies these costs could be lowered but would remain slightly higher than prices without CCS technologies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=David|first1=Jeremy|last2=Herzog|first2=Howard|title=The Cost of Carbon Capture|journal=BASE|date=2012|url=https://sequestration.mit.edu/pdf/David_and_Herzog.pdf|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
=== Energy requirements === The energy requirements of sequestration processes may be significant. In one paper, sequestration consumed 25 percent of the plant's rated 600 megawatt output capacity.<ref>{{cite conference|url=https://bioenergykdf.net/sites/default/files/zpdfzholderz/NREL_Data/KC_091102094516.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Net Energy and Global Warming Potential of Biomass Power compared to Coal-fired Electricity with CO2 Sequestration – A Life Cycle Approach |first1=Pamela L. |last1=Spath |first2=Margaret K. |last2=Mann |conference=Bioenergy 2002 Bioenergy for the Environment |location=Boise, Idaho |date=September 22, 2002 |access-date=August 21, 2015 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> :''After adding CO<sub>2</sub> capture and compression, the capacity of the coal-fired power plant is reduced to 457 MW.''
