The '''agrarian reform law of 1920''' in [[Latvia]] sought to transfer most of the land from [[Baltic nobility|Baltic German nobles]] to Latvian farmers. On September 16, 1920 [[Constitutional Assembly of Latvia]] passed the law of the Land reform, which would break up large landholdings and redistribute land to those peasants who worked it and to the newly created Latvian State Land Fund.<ref>[https://www.ucis.pitt.edu/nceeer/1996-810-23-3-Plakans.pdf Agrarian Reform in Latvia] University Center for International Studies</ref> Similar land reforms were carried out in [[Estonia]] ( September 24, 1920 ), [[Lithuania]] ( March 29, 1922 ) and [[Poland]] ( December 28, 1925 ). == Background == Before the [[World War I]] some 2% of landowners owned 53% of land in [[Kurzeme Planning Region|Kurzeme]] and [[Vidzeme]], in [[Latgale]] it was 38%. The Agrarian reform Law of September 16, 1920 created State Land Fund which took over 61% of all land.
== Objective == The main objectives of the reform were several - the creation of new farms and the expansion of already existing smallholder farms, by so doing, the division of land of former large-scale farms into smaller land areas, thereby acquiring land for the creation of new farms. The creation of various economic enterprises, the satisfaction of social and cultural needs, is understood as implicit agrarian reform tasks as a consequence of the implementation of the reform. The aim of the reform was also to find opportunities for the expansion of cities and towns, which means that the territories borrowed from the state reserve reserved areas for the development of populated areas. == Land reform law == The various parts of Land reform law has been adopted by [[Constitutional Assembly of Latvia]] at different times: *Part I "On the Establishment of the State Land Fund" (paragraph 26) was adopted on 16 September, 1920. *Part II "On the Use of the State Land Fund" (Paragraph 19) was adopted by the Plenary Session of the Constituent Assembly on December 21, 1920. *Part III "On strengthening agrarian reform" was issued on May 3, 1922. *The Law "On the Transfer of the Land Allotted to Private Ownership or Grant in the Hire of a Family " was issued on April 23rd, 1923. *Part IV "On Land Surveillance Committees" (paragraph 21) was adopted on 17 September, 1920.
The Land reform law expropriated the [[manor]] lands. Landowners were left with 50 hectares each and their land was distributed to the landless peasants without cost. In 1897, 61.2% of the rural population had been landless; by 1936, that percentage had been reduced to 18%. The extent of cultivated land surpassed the pre-war level already in 1923.<ref>{{cite book| last = Bleiere| first = Daina |author2=Ilgvars Butulis |author3=Antonijs Zunda |author4=Aivars Stranga |author5=Inesis Feldmanis| title = History of Latvia : the 20th century.| publisher = [[Jumava (publisher)|Jumava]]| location = [[Riga]]| pages = 195| year = 2006| isbn = 9984-38-038-6| oclc = 70240317}}</ref>
Before the World War I some 2% of landowners owned 53% of land in Kurzeme and Vidzeme, in Latgale it was 38%. The Agrarian reform Law of September 16, 1920 created State Land Fund which took over 61% of all land. The German nobles were left with no more than 50 ha of land. This destroyed their manor house system. Many of them sold their possessions and left for Germany. Former manor house buildings often were used as local schools, administrative buildings or hospitals. The land was distributed to a new class of small-holding farmers - over 54,000 Jaunsaimnieki (New farmers) with average farm size of 17,1 ha, who usually had to create their farms from nothing, in process building new houses and clearing fields. Due to their small size and unfavorable grain prices, the new farmers rapidly developed dairy farming. Butter, bacon and eggs became new export industries. == Economic results == The agrarian reform was finally completed in 1937, transforming the country's economy and the Latvian society. Agrarian reform can be regarded as a [[social revolution]] in which the foundations of changing agriculture were created from large-scale farms with large but economically inefficient farming units on small farms. Legislators counted on emerging farms as economically productive, viable and cost-effective entities at the time. Although many foreign economists questioned the economic justification of such a radical reform because it required huge investments - about 700 million lats, and therefore predicted an economic downturn. However agrarian reform lead to a rapid economic growth due to increased productivity, increased agricultural output per hectare and increased size of productive agricultural land. When starting agrarian reform, Danish agriculture was largely a model, because it seemed most suitable for Latvia. Already in 1930, at the beginning of the year, the country was fully supplied with agricultural products and exports began to grow. In 1938 Latvia as the milk and meat exporter ranked fourth behind Denmark, Netherlands and Sweden. == Social consequences and owners compensation== The driving force behind agrarian reform was more political than economic. As a result of agrarian reform the country's main natural treasures - land and forests changed it owners. The inherited feudal power over the state's main economic sectors was broken with elimination of feudal [[manor]] system, which connected inherited [[mansion]]s ([[:de:Rittergut|Rittergut]]) with land around it. At the same time, the social problems of counter-terrorism, which had radicalized the entire nation, were solved.
The previous landowners affected by the reforms, mostly ethnic [[Baltic Germans]], did not received any compensation, however they were left with small fraction of previously owned land.
In 1924 the Baltic Germans demanded a payment of 1200 million [[gold franc]]s for expropriated land properties through a group of six their representatives in Latvia's parliament. However just before the crucial vote on the 30th of April 1924, the Baltic German faction abandoned the hearing room, which led to the dismissal of the claim by a small majority. Later, the German-speaking parliamentary faction appealed against the State of Latvia in the [[League of Nations]], requesting compensation for seized land, but that claim was also rejected.
In 1929 Latvia signed an agreement with Poland, which resolved the controversial issues that were mostly related to the Latgale region. The Latvian government paid 5 million lats for estates that were expropriated from [[Polish noblemen]] in course of agrarian reform.<ref name="letonica">[https://www.letonika.lv/groups/default.aspx?cid=31790 1920 - 1937 Agrārā reforma ] {{lang-lv|Latvijas vēstures enciklopēdija}} </ref>

The [[Democratic National Committee]] (DNC) '''Lawrence O'Brien Award''' was created in 1992 by the family of [[Larry O'Brien|Lawrence Francis "Larry" O'Brien Jr.]] (1917-1990) and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] leaders to recognize the many years of service he gave to the party and his belief in the contribution of party [[Volunteering|volunteer]]s. Since then, party leaders presented this award on five occasions to 94 winners from across the [[United States]].
The award honors the importance of this contribution to the continuing success and vitality of the party. It's given to individuals and groups who exhibit a high degree of commitment and self-sacrifice on behalf of the party and its [[candidate]]s.
The award was expanded in 1998 to help mark the 150th anniversary of the DNC. Party leaders honored an individual or group from every [[commonwealth (United States)|commonwealth]], [[district]], [[U.S. state|state]] and [[territory (country subdivision)|territory]] and six individuals nationally.<ref name = "1998 Lawrence O'Brien Awards: Recognizing Democratic Party Achievement">{{Cite conference | first = Steve | last = Grossman | authorlink = |author2=Gov. Roy Romer | title = | booktitle = 1998 Lawrence O'Brien Awards: Recognizing Democratic Party Achievement | pages = | publisher = Democratic National Committee | date = 1998-09-26 | location = Washington | url = | doi = | id = | accessdate =}}</ref> Through the generosity of the O'Brien family, award winners also received financial grants.
A news report which was published in 2000 by ''[[Insight (magazine)|Insight]]'' magazine described a 1998 controversy about e-mail messages which were written between [[Bill Clinton|Clinton]]-[[Al Gore|Gore]] [[Administration (government)|Administration]] staff members and [[1996 U.S. Presidential Election|1996 presidential reelection campaign]] staffers about political [[fundraising]] by Administration staffers. Some of the messages were written in 1996 and solicited the award for a campaign contributor.
==Selection==
Award winners are selected from among many [[nomination]]s received from party leaders, appointed and elected [[public official]]s, and other Democrats in the United States. Each winner worked at the local-, state- or national-party levels, including assisting candidates for elected public office. Furthermore, the winners made personal, family or financial sacrifices, or otherwise showed unusual or extraordinary dedication to the furtherance of the goals of the party, without financial remuneration or professional gain.

[[Reno, Nevada]] (2011) |country = United States |first = 2011 |organizer = [[Campaign for Liberty]] |filing = Non-profit |attendance = Around 1,000 |website = {{url|http://www.lpac.com}} }} The '''Liberty Political Action Conference''' ('''LPAC''') was an annual political conference attended by [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] and [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]] [[Activism|activists]] and elected officials from across the [[United States]]. The conference was held from 2011 to 2014, in various locations. LPAC is hosted by [[Campaign for Liberty]], a [[501(c)(4)]] [[nonprofit]] that is currently chaired by former Congressman [[Ron Paul]] of Texas. ==History== The first Liberty Political Action Conference took place prior to the 2012 Republican primary season from September 15-17, 2011 in [[Reno]], [[Nevada]]. Speakers at the conference included Ron Paul, Senators [[Rand Paul]] and [[Mike Lee (U.S. politician)|Mike Lee]], Congressman [[Steve Stockman]], actors [[Vince Vaughn]] and [[Jerry Doyle]], [[Chuck Baldwin]], and [[Debra Medina]], among others.{{cite web |url=http://www.jbs.org/commentary/join-jbs-at-lpac-2011-in-reno-sept-15-17 |title=Join JBS at LPAC 2011 in Reno, Sept. 15-17 |publisher=John Birch Society |accessdate=2013-04-05 |date=2011-09-06}} The second LPAC took place following the 2012 Republican primary season, from September 13-15, 2012, and prior to the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]] in [[Chantilly, Virginia|Chantilly]], [[Virginia]] outside of [[Washington, D.C.]]. Speakers at the conference included Ron Paul, Senators Rand Paul, Mike Lee, [[Jim DeMint]] and [[Ted Cruz]], Congressman [[Justin Amash]] and [[Scott Garrett]], actor Jerry Doyle, [[Mallory Factor]], and Virginia Attorney General [[Ken Cuccinelli]], among others.{{cite web |url=http://www.independentamericanparty.org/2012/08/lpac-2012-heats-up/ |title=LPAC 2012 Heats Up |publisher=Independent American Party |accessdate=2013-04-05 |date=2012-08-21}} The third LPAC conference took place in Chantilly, Virginia from September 19-22, 2013. The fourth LPAC conference took place in Alexandria, Virginia from September 18-20, 2014, but there was never a confirmation of an event held in 2015. ===Locations=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col" | ! scope="col" | Hosting city ! scope="col" | Attendees ! scope="col" | Date ! scope="col" | Hosting venue |- ! scope="row"| 1 | [[Reno, Nevada]] | 700 | September 15 – 17, 2011 | [[Grand Sierra Resort]] |- ! scope="row"| 2 |[[Chantilly, Virginia]] | | September 13 – 15, 2012 | [[Marriott Hotels & Resorts|Westfields Marriott]] |- ! scope="row"|3 |[[Chantilly, Virginia]] | | September 19 – 22, 2013 | [[Marriott Hotels & Resorts|Westfields Marriott]] |- !4 |[[Alexandria, Virginia]] | |September 18 - 20, 2014 |Hilton Alexandria Mark Center |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[Campaign for Liberty]] ==External links== * [http://www.lpac.com Liberty Political Action Conference], ''official website'' [[Category:Political conferences]] [[Category:Political conventions in the United States]] [[Category:Conservatism in the United States]] [[Category:Libertarianism in the United States]]

[[Helsinki]] | coordinates = | employees = 250{{cite web |url=http://mmm.fi/ministerio |title=Maa- ja metsätalousministeriö |publisher=Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry |access-date=20 January 2017 |language=fi}} | budget = €2.595 billion | minister1_name = [[Jari Leppä]] | minister1_pfo = [[Minister of Agriculture and Forestry (Finland)|Minister of Agriculture and Forestry]] | chief1_name = Jaana Husu-Kallio | chief1_position = | chief2_name = | chief2_position = | chief3_name = | chief3_position = | chief4_name = | chief4_position = | chief5_name = | chief5_position = | chief6_name = | agency_type = | chief6_position = | chief7_name = | chief7_position = | chief8_name = | chief8_position = | chief9_name = | chief9_position = | parent_department = | parent_agency = | child1_agency = | child2_agency = | keydocument1 = | website = {{URL|http://mmm.fi/}} | footnotes = | map = | map_width = | map_caption = }} {{Politics of Finland}} The '''Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry''' ('''MMM''', {{lang-fi|maa- ja metsätalousministeriö}}, {{lang-sv| jord- och skogsbruksministeriet}}) is [[List of Finnish ministries|one of the 12 ministries]] in the [[Finnish Government]]. Natural resources and their sustainable use are in the focus of this ministry.{{cite web |url=http://mmm.fi/en/ministry |title= Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry |publisher= Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry |access-date= 20 January 2017}} It also makes sure that Finland is self-sufficient in its food production even in a time of crisis, and that the food production and use of natural resources is sustainable, economically beneficial, and good for the well-being of the nation's citizens.{{cite web |url=http://mmm.fi/en/task-and-objectives |title= Task and objectives |publisher= Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry |access-date= 20 January 2017}} For 2018, the MMM's budget is [[Euro|€]]2,594,529,000.{{Cite web|url=http://www.valtionbudjetti.fi/|title=Valtionbudjetti.fi: talousarvioesitys 2018 visualisoituna|website=Valtionbudjetti.fi|access-date=2018-03-21}} The ministry has about 250 employees.{{Cite web|url=http://mmm.fi/ministerio|title=Ministeriö|website=Maa- ja metsätalousministeriö|language=fi-FI|access-date=2018-03-21}} == History == The predecessor of the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry was founded by [[Alexander II of Russia|Alexander II]] in 1860, 57 years prior to [[Finnish Declaration of Independence|Finland's independence]]. "Forestry" was added to the name and task of the ministry in 1971. In 1983, environmental matters were moved to newly-founded [[Ministry of the Environment (Finland)|Ministry of the Environment]].{{cite web |url=http://mmm.fi/historiaa |title=Maa- ja metsätalousministeriön historiaa |publisher=Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry |access-date=20 January 2017 |language=fi}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://mmm.fi/}} {{Finnish Ministries}} [[Category:Government ministries of Finland|Agriculture]] [[Category:Agriculture ministries|Finland]] [[Category:Forestry ministries|Finland]] [[Category:Agriculture in Finland]]

{{pp|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=July 2016}} {{refimprove|date=July 2016}} }} [[File:JMUN UNSC.jpg|thumb|Delegates attending a committee session at Jakarta MUN (JMUN) in Jakarta, Indonesia|alt=Delegates attending a committee]] [[File:TIMUN08OpeningCeremony.jpg|thumb|Conference assembly at Turkish International Model United pagal in [[Istanbul|Istanbul, Turkey]]|alt=Conference assembly]] '''Model United Nations''', also known as '''Model UN''' or '''MUN''', is an educational simulation and/or academic activity in which students can learn about [[diplomacy]], [[international relations]], and the [[United Nations]]. MUN involves and teaches participants speaking, debating, and writing skills, in addition to [[critical thinking]], teamwork, and [[leadership]] abilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/what-is-model-united-nations/|title=What is Model United Nations?|work=Best Delegate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.model-un.de/en/was-ist-mun/ |title=What does "Model United Nations" mean? |publisher=model-un.de |accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> Usually an extracurricular activity, some schools also offer Model UN as a class. It is meant to engage students and allow them to develop deeper understanding into current world issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.winthrop.edu/modelun/default.aspx?id=26613 |title=Model UN - Courses - Winthrop University |publisher=Winthrop University|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref>
Participants in Model United Nations conferences, known as delegates, are placed in committees and assigned countries to represent, or occasionally other organizations or political figures, where they represent members of that body. They are presented with their assignments in advance, along with a topic or topics that their committee will discuss. Delegates conduct research before conferences and formulate positions that they will then [[debate]] with their fellow delegates in the committee, staying true to the actual position of the member they represent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/how-to-participate/getting-started/frequently-asked-questions#what_is |title=Getting Started - What is MUN? |publisher=UNA-USA |accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> At the end of a conference, the best-performing delegates in each committee, as well as delegations, are sometimes recognized with awards.
Model UN participants include students at middle school, high school, and college/university levels, with most conferences catering to just one of these three levels (high school and college conferences being most common).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mymun.net/muns/list |title=List of MUN Conferences by High School and College level |publisher=MyMUN.net |accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> Delegates usually attend conferences together as delegations sent by their respective schools' or universities' Model UN clubs, though some delegates attend conferences independently.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/independent-model-un-teams/|title=The Sudden Rise of Independent Model UN Teams: Homeschool, Community, and Private Travel Teams|work=Best Delegate}}</ref>
== History == Model UN began as a series of student-led Model [[League of Nations]] simulations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.munplanet.com/articles/model-united-nations/toward-a-history-of-model-united-nations|title=Toward a History of Model United Nations|first=KOvacevic|last=Marko|work=MUNPlanet}}</ref> It is believed that the first Model League of Nations conferences were held in the 1920s, before transitioning to Model UN after the formation of the League's successor organization, the [[United Nations]], in 1945.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/how-to-participate/getting-started/frequently-asked-questions#how_did|title=Frequently Asked Questions|first=Ross|last=Feldman|work=United Nations Association of the USA}}</ref> Today, some Model United Nations conferences include simulations of the League of Nations among their committee offerings.
The first Model United Nations was held at St. Lawrence University from 11–13 February 1949.<ref>"Ten Colleges Participate in Model Session of United Nations Held at S. L.U. Campus," ''Watertown Daily Times'', 14 February 1949.</ref> It was initiated by Dr. Harry Reiff, Head of the History and Government Department, with the assistance of departmental colleague Otto L. George.<ref>"Ten Schools Form Synthetic UN Group," ''Hill News'', 3 February 1949.</ref> Dr. Reiff was a technical advisor on the [[United States]] delegation to the 1945 San Francisco Conference (where the UN Charter was written) and the UN Organizational Conference in [[London]] in 1945-46 (where the UN was established).<ref>''Who's Who in America'' (Chicago: A. N. Marquis) vol. 31, 1960, p. 2394.</ref> The 1949 St. Lawrence University Model UN conference included delegates from regional conferences and universities, including Adelphi, Alfred, Champlain, Clarkson, McGill, Middlebury, Potsdam, St. Michael's, and Vermont.<ref>"To Conduct Model Security / Ten Colleges to Follow United Nations Procedure / Sessions Will Take Place on St. Lawrence Campus February 11–13," ''St. Lawrence Plaindealer'' [Canton, N. Y.], 25 January 1949.</ref><ref>"SLU I. R. Sponsors Model UN Meeting," ''Commercial Advertiser'' [Canton, N. Y.], 1 February 1949.</ref><ref>"St. Lawrence IRC Host to 9 Colleges," ''Hill News'' [Canton, N.Y.] 9 February 1949.</ref> The conference continued annually for many years at St. Lawrence <ref>Pink, Louis H. and Rutherford E. Delmage, ''Candle in the Wilderness: A Centennial History of the St. Lawrence University'', 1856-1956 (New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts, Inc., 1957). p. 157.</ref><ref>Edward H. Blankman and Thurlow O. Cannon, ed. by Neal S. Burdick, ''The Scarlet and the Brown: A History of St .Lawrence University 1856-1981'' (Canton, New York: St Lawrence University, 1987), p. 56.</ref> and has recently been revived on the campus.<ref>Duell, Ryan, "Rise Fall Rise Again," ''St. Lawrence University Magazine'', LXIV, 4 (2015), pp. 18-19.</ref> Other Model UN conference were developed later at Berkeley, Harvard and the National Model United Nations <ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/berkeley-model-united-nations-bmun-xli-transformation-into-a-true-teaching-conference/|title=Berkeley Model United Nations (BMUN XLI): Transformation Into a True Teaching Conference|work=Best Delegate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/berkeley-bmun-60/|title=Berkeley Model United Nations Celebrates 60th Year as the First and Oldest MUN Conference in the World|work=Best Delegate}}</ref> [[Harvard Model United Nations#Harvard Model United Nations|Harvard Model United Nations (HMUN)]], and National Model United Nations (NMUN NY) as well as many other colleges and universities.
In 1987, a few American exchange students founded TEIMUN in [[The Hague]]. In recent decades, Model UN has spread to East and South Asia, the Middle East, Europe, North Africa, and sub-Saharan Africa. Other major conference organizers such as Indian International Model United Nations, Harvard, THIMUN establishing additional conferences in these regions to meet burgeoning demand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/which-countries-love-model-un-the-most-analysis-of-the-g20-countries-of-best-delegate-fans/|title=Which Countries Love Model UN the Most? Analysis of the G20 Countries of Best Delegate Fans|work=Best Delegate}}</ref> The Ivy League Model United Nations, an arm of the Model UN at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], hosts conferences for high-school-aged delegates in India and China, as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilmunc-india.com |title=Welcome to ILMUNC India |publisher=Ilmunc-india.com |date=26 November 2015 |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Christine Du |url=http://www.ilmunc-china.com |title=ILMUNC China |publisher=ILMUNC China |date= |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>
== Procedures == [[File:MUN-SH2005KielGermany.jpg|thumb|Delegates negotiating during an unmoderated caucus]] In order to maintain [[Decorum#Social decorum|decorum]], most Model UN committees use parliamentary procedure derived from [[Robert's Rules of Order]]. However, most crisis committees forgo the formality of parliamentary procedure so as to ensure smoother operation. In addition, recently the United Nations has spearheaded efforts to introduce new Model UN rules of procedure that are more closely aligned with those used by the actual UN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/un4mun-workshop-recap-4-big-differences-between-model-un-and-the-real-un/|title=UN4MUN Workshop Recap: 4 Big Differences Between Model UN and the Real UN|work=Best Delegate}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/14/opinion/the-un-on-the-model-un.html?smid=pl-share&_r=0|title=Letter: The U.N., on the Model U.N.|author=[[Maher Nasser]]|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/en/ga/about/ropga/|title=UN General Assembly - Rules of Procedure|work=un.org}}</ref><ref name="MUN Rules">{{cite web |url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/how-to-participate/model-un-preparation/rules-of-procedure |title=Rules of Procedure |publisher=United Nations Foundation |accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> Since there is no [[Board of governors|governing body]] for MUNs, each conference differs in the rules of procedure. The following rules of procedure apply to general MUNs but may not apply to every MUN:
MUNs are run by a group of [[Business administration|administrators]] known as the dais. A dais is headed by a [[Secretary-General]]. Each committee usually has a chair (also known as moderator), a member of the dais that enforces the rules of procedure. A [[delegate]] may request the committee as a whole to perform a particular action; this is known as a motion. Documents aiming to address the issue of the committee are known as resolutions and are voted for ratification.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/how-to-participate/getting-started/model-un-glossary |title=Model UN Glossary |publisher=United Nations Foundation |accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref>
MUN committees can be divided into three general sessions: formal [[debate]], moderated [[caucus]], and unmoderated caucus. In a formal debate, the staff maintains a list of speakers and the delegates follow the order written on the 'speaker list'. Speakers may be added to the speaker list by raising their [[placard]]s or sending a note to the chair. During this time, delegates talk to the entire committee. They make [[speech]]es, answer questions, and debate on resolutions and amendments. If there are no other motions, the committee goes back to formal debate by default. There is usually a [[time limit]]. In a moderated caucus, the committee goes into a recess and the rules of procedure are suspended. Anyone may speak if recognized by the chair. A vote on a motion is necessary to go into a moderated caucus. There is a comparatively shorter time limit per speech. In an unmoderated caucus, the delegates informally meet with other delegates and the staff for discussions.<ref name="MUN Rules" /><ref name="MUN Manifesto">{{cite web |last =Shen |first=Sunny |author2=Ryan Bae |author3=Amanda Chen |author4=Geneva Nam |author5=Sarah Wang |author6=Marco Wong |author7=Lance Zhou |title=The MUN Manifesto |publisher=Connect Global Youth Association |year=2012 |url=http://project-connect.ca/resources/MUNManifesto.pdf |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
[[Resolution (law)|Resolution]]s are the basis of all debate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.utk.edu/~modelun/resolutions.htm |title=What is a Resolution? |publisher=University of Tennessee |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> They are considered the final results of [[conversation]]s, [[writing]]s, and [[negotiation]]s. Resolutions must go through a [[Draft document|draft]], approval by the dais, and consequent debate and modification.<ref name="Resolution">{{cite web |url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/how-to-participate/model-un-preparation/resolutions |title=Resolutions |publisher=United Nations Foundation |accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
== Academic aspects == Participation in Model UN is meant to foster [[negotiation]], [[public speaking|speaking]] and [[communication skills]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://socialsciences.uottawa.ca/international/opportunities/un-course|title=Model United Nations Course {{!}} Faculty of Social Sciences {{!}} University of Ottawa|website=socialsciences.uottawa.ca|language=en|access-date=20 February 2017}}</ref> In addition, crisis committees, which deal with [[crisis]] [[scenario]]s which can be contemporary or historical, can develop leadership skills and the ability to adapt and deal with unexpected situations. Material issues of [[diplomacy]] and [[policy]] are also approached through a quasi-academic process. In preparation for a conference, topics are chosen for each committee, and typically, research and background guides (called Study Guides) are made available by the organizers of a conference for each committee. Delegates of each committee are often expected to pre-formulate the position of the country or group they represent, based on these background guides, and submit the result of this preparation to their committee as a so-called Position Paper.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/how-to-participate/model-un-preparation/position-papers|title=Position Papers|last=Feldman|first=Ross|newspaper=United Nations Association of the USA|access-date=20 February 2017|language=en-gb}}</ref> The purpose of this procedure is to familiarize delegates with the substantial topics of debate, encourage [[academic research]] and writing, and to enable substantial preparation for conferences.
While several guides on the techniques of writing Position Papers, including templates and examples, are available,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unitedambassadors.com/single-post/2016/05/02/How-to-Write-a-Great-Position-Paper-for-a-Model-United-Nations-Conference|title=United Ambassadors for Model United Nations|website=United Ambassadors for Model United Nations|access-date=20 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aps.schoolwires.com/Page/12903|title=Model United Nations / Writing a Position Paper|website=aps.schoolwires.com|language=en|access-date=20 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170221010038/http://aps.schoolwires.com/Page/12903|archive-date=21 February 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bestdelegate.com/a-formula-for-the-perfect-position-paper-solution-oriented-research/|title=A Formula for the Perfect Position Paper: Solution-Oriented Research|newspaper=Best Delegate|access-date=20 February 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> no conferences publish their Study Guides, Position Papers or Resolutions.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} Currently, only one subscription-based Position Paper database is available.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mymun.net/position-paper-database|title=Position Paper Database|last=|first=|date=20 February 2017|website=MyMUN.net|access-date=}}</ref> Mun is not arguing the nature of a question, proving research facts, or standing up and defending a foreign policy agenda but providing solutions that every nation, human and nature can endeavour and use to resolve crises and rise in the risk of uniting strength to maintain international peace and security. This is the difference between the parliament and the UN, distinguishing power struggle from diplomacy.
== Languages == [[File:Buenos Aires MINU UN Model - 2007-11-06 - 4.jpg|thumb|Placard for the [[United Kingdom]] in Spanish at the International Model United Nations of Buenos Aires (MINUBA) in [[Argentina]]]] Traditionally, [[English language|English]] has been the official and working language of most conferences, but, as Model UN has become more popular around the world, and as conferences in countries such as the United States have sought to appeal to underrepresented minorities (such as the [[Spanish language|Spanish]]-speaking community), committees using languages other than English, or which are [[multilingualism|bilingual]], have become common.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/model-un-conferences/model-un-city-conferences/minnesota|title=Global Classrooms: Minnesota Model UN Conference|first=Ross|last=Feldman|work=United Nations Association of the USA}}</ref> It should be noted, however, that this is still not yet a mainstream phenomenon, especially not in the United States, where most bilingual or Spanish language committees are found at conferences hosted in [[Puerto Rico]] or the [[Southern United States|South]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/model-united-nations-san-antonio-munsa-finds-success-through-community/|title=Model United Nations San Antonio (MUNSA) Finds Success Through Community|work=Best Delegate}}</ref>, apart from Spain.
== Attire == Nearly all Model United Nations conferences require delegates to wear [[Informal attire|Western business attire]], as dressing professionally is an important way to show respect for the nation, organization, or individual one is representing, as well as for the rest of one's committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unausa.org/global-classrooms-model-un/how-to-participate/model-un-preparation/dressing-for-success|title=Dressing for Success|first=Ross|last=Feldman|work=United Nations Association of the USA}}</ref>
== Committees == While Model United Nations conferences regularly simulate the bodies of the United Nations, the [[European Union]], government [[Cabinet (government)|cabinets]], and regional bodies such as [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] as so-called Committees, as well as corporate [[Board of directors|boards]], [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]] or so-called [[Press corps|Press Corps]], idiosyncrasies and fictional Committees also exist. An example for such a special committee that does not have a parallel in the actual [[United Nations]] which deals with a [[crisis]] is known as a 'Crisis Committee.'<ref name="Crisis NYT">{{cite news |last=Parrin |first=Anjli |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/04/education/edlife/a-new-student-run-breed-crisis-oriented-and-fiercely-competitive.html?_r=0 |title=The Dog-Eat-Dog World of Model U.N. |publisher=The New York Times Company |date=2 August 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> In this committee, a crisis is given to a team of students and the teams must come up with solutions.<ref>{{cite news |last=Montero |first=Nicole |url=http://fiusm.com/2013/11/22/model-united-nations-team-hopes-to-rank-first-among-the-country/ |title=Model United Nations Team Hopes to Rank First Among the Country |publisher=FIU Student Media |date=22 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> The Crisis Committee traditionally focuses on a single historical event, but recently current and future events have been used as well. The event may be [[fiction]]al or [[non-fiction]]al.<ref name="Crisis NYT" />
== Organization == Model United Nations conferences are usually organized by [[high school club]]s or [[college]] clubs.<ref name="What MUN">{{cite web |last=Yossinger |first=Nili Sarit |url=http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/publication/2012/07/2012073142614.html#axzz2lSH4DnI0 |title=What is Model UN? (And Why Should You Care?) |publisher=U.S. Department of State |date=23 August 2012 |accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref>

Leslie, The United Nations Association of the United States of America, 2004 edition (October 2004), softcover, 296 pages, {{ISBN|1-880632-71-3}}. * ''[https://www.munplanet.com/articles/munplanet/munplanet-ebook-becoming-a-model-un-delegate-an-essential-guide-through-the-mun-world Becoming a Model UN Delegate - An Essential Guide Through the MUN World]'', edited by Marko Kovacevic of MUNPlanet (August 2016) * ''[https://www.munplanet.com/articles/organizing-mun/munplanet-ebook-organizing-successful-model-un-conference-download Organizing Successful MUNs - practices, trends, innovation]'', edited by Marko Kovacevic of MUNPlanet (2015) * ''[http://www.engagingtheun.com Engaging the United Nations: A Brief Introduction to the UN]''. Brian Dille. Engagement Learning. 2017. {{ISBN|9780998851808}}
== Model UN by region and country == {{Main article|List of Model United Nations conferences}} Although Model United Nations originated in the United States, MUN clubs and conferences are not isolated to that country. Rather, like the actual UN, Model UN is found in countries around the globe.<ref name="bestdelegate.com">{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/model-un-conferences-database/|title=Model United Nations Conference Database: 2014-2015|work=bestdelegate.com}}</ref> Because Model UN is decentralized and has grown autonomously around the world, there are significant differences in how MUN is done between regions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestdelegate.com/a-tale-of-two-coasts-5-key-differences-between-west-coast-versus-east-coast-model-un/|title=A Tale of Two Coasts: 5 Key Differences Between West Coast versus East Coast Model UN|work=Best Delegate}}</ref>
===Denmark===
MUN is relatively popular in Denmark, with conferences at both [[Gymnasium (school)|high-school]] and university level. It was first introduced in 2003,<ref name=EGMUN>{{cite web|title=Previous MUNs|url=http://egmun.org/previous-muns/|website=egmun.org|accessdate=24 February 2016}}</ref> it has since spread with 3 major conferences at high-school level, with at least 400 participants at each conference,<ref name=EGMUN /><ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome 2016|url=https://www.facebook.com/bigmunconference/photos/a.635001486565559.1073741825.354614017937642/1023540374378333/?type=3&theater|website=Facebook.com|publisher=BIGMUN|accessdate=24 February 2016}}</ref> with BIGMUN being the largest conference in Scandinavia.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Menzer|first1=Joram Gregers|title=Tomorrow's problem solvers are ready|url=http://sn.dk/Rudersdal/Morgendagens-problemloesere-sidder-klar/artikel/556049|website=sn.dk|accessdate=29 February 2016|language=Danish}}</ref>
=== Spain === MUN has become popular in Spain at the beginning of this decade, hosting the largest number of Conferences in Madrid. One of them is the [https://compimun.com/ Complutense International Model of United Nations (COMPIMUN)], that will include for its third edition other international organisations such as the [[Asia Cooperation Dialogue]], or the [[September 11 attacks|9-11]], apart from the traditional UN related Committees.
=== The Netherlands ===
The largest MUN in the Netherlands is The Hague International Model United Nations (THIMUN) conference, which includes over 3500 participants coming from around 200 schools and 100 different countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thimun.org/9-features/2-thimun-conference|title=THIMUN Conference The Hague|publisher=THIMUN Foundation|accessdate=1 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006070307/http://www.thimun.org/9-features/2-thimun-conference|archivedate=6 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Although it is not located near the United-Nations Headquarters in New-York, it is one of the pioneer Model United Nations conferences in the world, since it has been founded in 1968 and located in the International Court of Justice's (ICJ) world city of the Hague. A whole network of conferences is marked by its THIMUN affiliation, a label which basically describes the universality of the procedures that rule the conference and make it part of the UN recognized foundation. In 1995 the THIMUN Foundation was accredited as a Non-Governmental Organisation (NGO) associated with the United Nations Department of Public Information.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thimun.org/index.php/youth-in-action|title=Youth In Action|publisher=THIMUN Foundation|accessdate=1 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208134107/http://www.thimun.org/index.php/youth-in-action|archive-date=8 December 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Also, the THIMUN has established its own conferences' network throughout time: THIMUN Qatar, THIMUN Singapore, THIMUN Online MUN (O-MUN) and THIMUN Latin America conferences have been set up from 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thimun.org/index.php/about/thimun-history|title=THIMUN History|publisher=THIMUN Foundation|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref> The second and third biggest MUN-conferences of the Netherlands are MUNISH (Model United Nations at the International School of the Hague and HMUN (Haarlem Model United Nations). There is also The European International Model UN TEIMUN which is founded in 1987 and is the oldest university Model UN in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teimun.org|title=The European International Model UN website}}</ref>
=== Turkey === {{Primary sources|date=May 2018}}
In Turkey, Model United Nations conferences are mostly held by non-profit university-clubs. [[Istanbul]] hosts more conferences than all Turkish other cities combined. Yeditepe Model United Nations Club, the oldest and one of the most popular clubs in Turkey, holds three different conferences, being, Yeditepe Model United Nations Training and Development [http://www.y-mun.org Conference], Justinianus Moot [http://www.justinianusmootcourts.org Courts], and Model United Nations Conference Istanbul (MUNIST)[http://munist2017.org]. Also, Koç University Model United Nations Conference (KUMUN)[http://kumun.ku.edu.tr], Kadir Has University Model United Nations Conference (HASMUN)[http://hasmun.org], alongside with the training conference of the Kadir Has University Model United Nations Training Conference (HASTRAIN), Izmir University of Economics Model United Nations Conference (ECOMUN)[https://web.archive.org/web/20170809233018/http://ecomun2017.org/], alongside with the training conference, İzmir University of Economics Training Conference (EcoTRAIN) are most qualified conferences in Turkey. These conferences simulate not only General Assembly committees, but also Joint Crisis Cabinets, Futuristic, Fictional and Historical timeline based committees.
=== United Kingdom ===
There are a very large number of Model United Nations conferences on both the University and Sixth Form level in the United Kingdom. Almost every university that has an MUN society holds a yearly conference, of varying size, with the largest and most prestigious being [[London International Model United Nations]] - so much so a features film was shot about it ([[Winning London]]), followed by [[CUIMUN]] hosted in Cambridge and [[OxiMUN]] in Oxford, however in recent years conferences such as [[YorkMUN]] and [[ScotMUN]] in Edinburgh have been gaining popularity amongst UK delegations. The UK MUN circuit is not particularly well integrated with the European circuit, with most UK delegations not crossing international borders to get to their conferences and international delegations to UK conferences outside of the big three a rarity, but recently European conferences have begun to recruit chairing staff quite heavily from the UK.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
=== Asia-Pacific ===
==== Afghanistan ==== The Kabul Model United Nations was established in [[Kabul]] in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/hamid-karzai-attacks-un-and-usa |title=Hamid Karzai Attacks UN and USA|author=Nabila Ashrafi |date=9 March 2017 |website=ToloNews |accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="MUN Kabul">{{cite web |url=http://munfinder.com/mun/kabul-model-united-nations/ |title=Kabul Model United Nations |website=MUN Finder |accessdate=12 March 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915115020/http://munfinder.com/mun/kabul-model-united-nations/ |archive-date=15 September 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The objectives are to bring young female and male individuals together to discuss [[global issue]]s and promote diplomacy, human rights, peace building, and social welfare.<ref name="MUN Kabul" /> Participants include university students up to the age of 30. They come from four or five Afghanistan provinces to develop critical thinking and public speaking skills.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://researchfunding.duke.edu/model-united-nations-conference-kabul-deadline-extended |title=Model United Nations Conference in Kabul -- Deadline Extended | author= |date= |website=Duke University - Research Funding |accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> Pamir International Model United Nations (PIMUN) was established by October 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sputniknews.com/asia/201608101044130808-afghanistan-un-model/ |title=United Nations Afghani-Style: Country Gets Its Own UN-Like Organization |date=8 October 2016 |website=Sputnik News |accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref>
==== Australia ==== Model United Nations conferences in Australia are typically separated into tertiary and high school levels. At the high school level, the large majority of Model United Nations events are organised by the various state and territory branches of UN Youth Australia,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://unyouth.org.au/event/the-evatt-competition/|title=The Evatt Competition|work=UN Youth Australia|accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref> or by the many branches of Rotary Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rotarynews.info/3/Club/76641/7833/ |title=Model United Nations Assembly (MUNA) : Rotary E-Club of Greater Sydney |publisher=Rotarynews.info |date=21 April 2014 |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref> Tertiary events, typically running for three to four days, occur within several Australian states, and are timed to coincide with holiday periods in tertiary semesters, with the largest three typically being VicMUN, NCMUN and SydMUN. Since 2013 another event was initiated globally in rotary world: [http://rotaractmun.org Rotaract Global Model United Nations] - international youth conference that already traveled from Baia Mare to London, Belgrade, New York, Sofia, Beirut and is set to take place in 2018 in Lithuania and India.
==== Bangladesh ==== {{Main article|Model United Nations in Bangladesh}} Model United Nations is practiced in [[Bangladesh]] since 2002. The first MUN to take place was the Model United Nations on Combating Terrorism - [[BANMUN|Bangladesh Model United Nations]] 2002.<ref>{{citation|url=http://unysab.org/?page_id=584|title=First Model United Nations: UNYSAB|first=|last=|publisher=‘‘UNYSAB’’|date=October 2013|accessdate=14 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150825233629/http://unysab.org/?page_id=584|archivedate=25 August 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/arts-culture/2015/aug/11/leaping-over-boundaries|title=Leaping over boundaries |first= |last= |publisher= [[Dhaka Tribune]]|date=11 August 2015 |accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref> Since then, plenty of Model United Nations conferencess have been held in the country. But the concept of MUN became a popular one in [[Bangladesh]] from 2013.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/education/2013/nov/16/creating-future|title=Creating the future |first= |last= |publisher= [[Dhaka Tribune]]|date=16 November 2013 |accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref>
United Nations Youth and Students Association of Bangladesh (UNYSAB) established MUN in Bangladesh. [[Bangladesh Model United Nations]] conferences include: Bangladesh International Model United Nations 2012; Dhaka+20, Brainwiz MUN 2013 and UNYSAB MUN 2014, organized by UNYSAB. Conferences of much larger numbers were organized by UNYSAB when they organized Bangladesh Model United Nations (BANMUN) Session VII in June 2015 with more than 560 delegates <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.banmun.com |accessdate=10 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109102930/http://banmun.com/ |archivedate=9 January 2016 }}</ref> and Bangladesh International Model United Nations (BIMUN) Session II in November 2015, with over 850 delegates, the largest number in Bangladesh's history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bimun.net|title=WELCOME TO BiMUN 2015|website=Bimun.net|accessdate=22 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202160300/http://bimun.net/|archive-date=2 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
MUN in Bangladesh grew rapidly after the formation of the first university based MUN club of the country [[Dhaka University]] Model United Nations Association in 2011.{{cn|date=May 2018}} Dhaka University National Model United Nations (DUNMUN) started from 2012.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/education/2014/dec/22/dunmun-2014-begins-dhaka-university|title=DUNMUN 2014 begins at Dhaka University|first=|last=|publisher=[[Dhaka Tribune]]|date=22 December 2014|accessdate=15 August 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923225203/http://www.dhakatribune.com/education/2014/dec/22/dunmun-2014-begins-dhaka-university|archive-date=23 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://bestdelegate.com/dhaka-university-national-model-united-nations-empowering-youths|title=Dhaka University National Model United Nations: Empowering Youths |first= |last= |publisher= BestDelegate.com|date=25 January 2015 |accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.newstoday.com.bd/index.php?option=details&news_id=2356844&date=2013-09-18|title=DUNMUN begins at DU |first= |last= |publisher= The News Today|date=18 September 2013 |accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref> Worlds largest Model UN brand from India, Indian International Model United Nations is also slated to conduct its chapter conference in Dhaka in February 2016.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
==== China ==== Model United Nations first came to China in 1995, when the elite [[China Foreign Affairs University]] held the country's first collegiate Model United Nations conferences.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://oversea.cnki.net/kcms/detail/detail.aspx?filename=WJXY503.015&DBName=cjfqtotal&dbcode=cjfq|title = 记外交学院首届模拟联合国活动 - China Academic Journals Full-text Database|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/special/2013-04/25/c_132339467.htm |title=Intro to CFAU-MUNA - Xinhua | English.news.cn |website=News.xinhuanet.com |date=25 April 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509164033/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/special/2013-04/25/c_132339467.htm |archive-date=9 May 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://zqb.cyol.com/html/2012-04/21/nw.D110000zgqnb_20120421_4-04.htm|title = 外交学院举办"2012北京模拟联合国大会"|date = |accessdate =22 January 2016 |website =Zqb.cyol.com |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Arriving in Chinese high schools in 2005, Model UN expanded rapidly. [[Peking University|Peking University (PKU)]] students, after attending [[Harvard College|Harvard]]'s [[Harvard Model United Nations|HMUN]], organized the first national Model UN conference for high school students in China. PKU's conference was initially backed by [[United Nations Association of the United States of America|UNA-USA]], however support was curtailed in 2010 due to the [[Great Recession]].
Between 2005 and 2010, national Model United Nations conferencess such as those organized by PKU and the rivaling Fudan University in Shanghai drew the best high school students from around the country, who competed for limited spaces. Over time, lesser-known national conferences, as well as regional and even local conferences for high school students, began to develop and gradually spread to cities beyond [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]].<ref name="theatlantic.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/04/romance-money-intrigue-its-model-un-in-china/275308/2/|title=Romance! Money! Intrigue! It's Model UN ... in China|first=Wendy|last=Qian|date=25 April 2013|work=The Atlantic}}</ref>
In the realm of interscholastic Model United Nations conferencess in China, the widely acknowledged{{According to whom|date=May 2018}} top 3 conferences are called "the ABC": [[Asian International Model United Nations]] held by [[Peking University]]; [http://www.bimun.org.cn/en/ Beijing International Model United Nations] held by [[China Foreign Affairs University]], and [[China National Model United Nations]], held by [[United Nations Association of China]], hosted in different cities annually. Another famous conference is the Annual NEOMUN conference, also known as SCAMUN by internal members.<ref>{{cite news|title=模拟联合国(MUN)简介|url=http://www.unachina.org/upload/Attach/default/272497.doc|publisher=U.N. Association of China|date=23 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115050959/http://www.unachina.org/upload/Attach/default/272497.doc|archivedate=15 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Most Model United Nations conferences in China are organized through private or academic enterprises, however some government-affiliated MUNs have also flourished, and recently, unofficial student-run grassroots conferences have begun to dominate the Chinese MUN scene.<ref name="theatlantic.com"/>
==== India ==== {{Primary|section|date=June 2018}} In 1996, the Cathedral Model United Nations was hosted by The Cathedral and John Connon School in Mumbai.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} Since then, schools and colleges in India started taking up Model United Nations as an activity in their school.
In 2011 [[VIBGYOR Group of Schools]] [http://www.vhmun.com Model United Nations (VHMUN)] was created. This simulation is organized by school students every year.{{cn|date=June 2018}}
In 2016, on 24, 25, 26 September. The Sri Sri Academy, in Kolkata organised its first Model United Nations Conference - SSMUN.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
In 2017, on 11 and 12 November, Symbiosis International School in Pune hosted the inaugural edition of its entirely student-organized Model UN conference, SymbiMUN. The founder and Secretary-General of the conference, Siddharth Baphna, along with his organizing team of Symbiosis students, collaborated with the education nonprofit Teach for India to train and sponsor twenty underprivileged children to participate. They donated all proceeds from the event to Teach for India, and plan to expand annually to give more underprivileged children Model UN opportunities.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
In the same year, 2017, a private Model UN conference was founded called the Backslash Model United Nations.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
In 2018, Siliguri Model United Nations is organising its inaugural conference, in collaboration with the United Nations.
In 2018 , a Model UN with a goal to help the underprivileged sections of society was founded called The Social Model United Nations (TSMUN) <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tsmun.co.in|title=TSMUN – The Social MUN|website=www.tsmun.co.in|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref>
In 2018, the [[Balvantray Mehta Vidya Bhawan ASMA|BMVB Model United Nations (BMVB MUN)]] conference was held in collaboration with the [[Servants of the People Society]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bmvbmun.org/home|title=BMVB Model United Nations|website=BMVB Model United Nations|language=en|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref>
==== Japan ==== [[File:KHSMUN GA.jpg|thumb|General Assembly of the Kansai High School Model United Nations at the [[Kyoto International Conference Center]], Kyoto, Japan.]] The Kansai High School Model United Nations (KHSMUN) is believed to be the first organised Model United Nations (MUN) conference aimed directly at high school [[English as a second or foreign language|English as a Foreign Language]] (EFL) students. The first conference was held in 1990 as a required project for third year students in [[Kyoto Gaidai Nishi High School]]'s Course of International and Cultural Studies. This conference included 40 KGNHS students and 13 students from [[Kansai International High School]] in [[Toyonaka, Osaka|Toyonaka]], [[Osaka Prefecture|Osaka]]. The two-day conference, held at [[Kyoto University of Foreign Studies]], simulated the Commission on Human Rights and debated the agenda item of the [[Israel]] and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] Conflict. The conference went on to become an annual gathering of high school students studying EFL in [[Japan]]. Unlike the majority of other MUN events around the world, the Kansai High School Model United Nations is a non-competitive MUN event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khsmun.com/2016/about.html |title=About the MUN, Kansai High School Model United Nations |publisher=KHSMUN Organising Committee |date= |accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" !Year !Conference Agenda |- |2013 |Water for Life |- |2014 |Global Food Security |- |2015 |The Rights of the Child |- |2016 |Protecting the Rights of Refugees |- |2017 |Reducing Inequality Through Sustainable Development |- |2018 |The Impact of Climate Change on Children |}
====Korea====
The largest MUN conference in Korea is the Seoul Model United Nations (SEOMUN) Conference, which includes hundreds of participants from around the world. It has been held on an annual basis since 1997. The hosting responsibility rotates between three international schools in Korea: [[Korea International School (South Korea)|Korea International School]], [[Seoul International School]], and [[Seoul Foreign School]]. The conference is usually held at the [[COEX Mall|Coex Mall]] in [[Gangnam District|Gangnam District, Seoul]].
{| class="wikitable" !Year !Conference Agenda |- |2015 |Freedom From Fear |- |2016 |Embracing Diversity |- |2017 |Global Populism and National Identity |- |2018 |The Perils of Indifference<ref>{{cite web|title=SEOMUN XXI|url=https://www.seomunxx.org/|website=SEOMUNXXI|publisher=Korea International School|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> |}
==== Taiwan ====
{{Unreferenced Section|date=May 2018}} The largest MUN conference in Taiwan is the Pan Asia MUN(PAMUN) Conference, which is held by National Taiwan University, also PAMUN is widely recognized{{By whom|date=May 2018}} as the most international MUN conference in Taiwan. There are also some regional MUN conference such as Taiwan Model United Nation (TWMUN) held by National Tsing Hua university(NTHU) and National Chiao Tung university(NCTU), Taipei Model United Nation (TMUN) held by National Chenchi University(NCCU), and Phoenix MUN held by National Cheng Kong University(NCKU). As opposed to in China, English is the usual official language of MUN in Taiwan except for some special committees which use Chinese as official language. There are also conferences for high school students in Taiwan, such as the Taiwan Model United Nation (TAIMUN) hosted by American School in Taichung, Southern Taiwan Model United Nation (STMUN) which take turns hosting by Kaohsiung American School and I-Shou International School. This trend is still booming. In 2017, the New Taipei City Model United Nations ([http://www.ntcmun.org/ NTCMUN]) was held in New Taipei City. With the resource and service of the local government, participants are allowed to attend for free; moreover it provides simultaneous interpretation equipment to help participants understand the process thoroughly. The second session of NTCMUN is about to launch in August, 2018.
====Thailand==== {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2018}}
MUN in Thailand is usually hosted by the international schools and universities in Thailand. Bangkok Patana School, Concordian International School, Ekamai International School, Harrow International School, International Seaboard Eastern School, [[NIST International School]], Chulalongkorn University and Thammasat University have all hosted Model United Nations conferences. These conferences are typically separated into university and high school levels. Model United Nations conferences are run by the school or the university club, with some guidance from their advisors. There are also conferences like ThaiMUN and APMUN, both are bigger than what the International School and university have hosted. APMUN was hosted by the Royal Thai Embassy on 20 to 24 September 2012. Unlike other Model United Nations conferences the APMUN and ThaiMUN are 3-4 day conferences, other Model United Nations conferences are usually hosted for 1 day. ThaiModel United Nations conferences are hosted by international schools or universities each year. Students from multiple international schools gather and form a host committee. The host committee decides where will ThaiMUN be hosted in that year. Thailand's MUN, unlike most Model United Nations conferences around the world, are non-competitive, and are intended to help students improve their academic and social skills .
==== Pakistan ==== '''Sindh:''' In the Province of Sindh Many of the Model United Nations have been organized by many Reputable Universities, Organizations and Educational Institutes.
'''Punjab:''' In the Province of Punjab Many of the Model United Nations have been organized by many reputable universities like [[Lahore University of Management Sciences]]. Punjab also has [[Pakistan]]'s first ever academy for MUNs known as The Model UN Academy. In the city of Bahawalpur, MUNs are organised by Army Public School and Sadiq Public School.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://modelunacademy.com/|title=Model UN Academy|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170716161020/http://modelunacademy.com/|archive-date=2017-07-16|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref>
