===IWA=== Though the Bolsheviks suppressed syndicalism in Russia, they courted syndicalists abroad as part of their international strategy. In March 1919, the [[Comintern]] or Third International was [[1st Congress of the Comintern|founded at a conference in Moscow]]. The Bolsheviks acknowledged syndicalism's opposition to socialist reformism and saw them as part of the revolutionary wing of the labor movement. No syndicalists attended the founding convention, mainly because the [[Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War|blockade of Russia]] by the Allies powers made travel to Moscow near impossible.<ref>Thorpe 1989, pg. 100–101, 104, Tosstorf 2009, pg. 15.</ref> After long discussions, the CNT opted to join the Comintern, though it classified its adherence as provisional as a concession to detractors of Bolshevism. USI also decided to join, though some like Borghi had reservations about the course of events in Russia. In France, the CGT's radical minority that had opposed the war enthusiastically supported Bolshevism. They formed the [[Revolutionary Syndicalist Committees]] and attempted to push the CGT as a whole to support the Comintern.<ref>Thorpe 1989, pg. 112–116.</ref> The General Executive Board of the IWW decided join the Comintern, but this decision was never confirmed by a convention.<ref>Thorpe 2017, pg. 109.</ref> German and Swedish syndicalists were more critical of Bolshevism from the start. Rocker declared already in August 1918 that the Bolshevik regime was "but a new system of tyranny" and they clashed on a number of issues.<ref>Thorpe 1989, pg. 116, 122, Tosstorf 2009, pg. 15.</ref>
The [[2nd World Congress of the Comintern|second congress of the Comintern]] in the summer of 1920 was attended by numerous syndicalists. The Italian USI, the Spanish CNT, the British shop stewards, and the revolutionary minority of the CGT had official representatives, but others like [[John Reed (journalist)|John Reed]] of the American IWW and [[Augustin Souchy]] of the German FAUD also attended in an unofficial capacity. Western syndicalists' knowledge of the facts on the ground in Russia was at this point rather limited. They thought of the soviets as organs of workers' control over production and the Bolsheviks depicted them as such. Syndicalists were not aware of the extent to which they were in reality subordinated to the communist party. The congress, however, revealed the irreconcilable differences between the syndicalist and the Bolshevik approach.<ref>Thorpe 1989, pg. 126–129, 132, Tosstorf 2009, pg. 16.</ref> Even before the congress, at a meeting of the Comintern's Executive Committee a document, a document was proposed that derided the apolitical unions as "lackeys of imperialist capitalism" for their betrayal during the war, to which syndicalists replied that of the syndicalist unions this only applied to the CGT.<ref>Thorpe 1989, pg. 132–133.</ref>
The [[International Workers' Association]], formed in 1922, is an international syndicalist federation of various labour unions from different countries. At its peak, it represented millions of workers and competed directly for the hearts and minds of the working class with social democratic unions and parties. <!-- Thorpe, Lehning, Darlingotn --> <!-- New movements emerged: Poland, Cuba, China--> <!-- Bock 339-340: IWA retarded growth of RILU -->
==Decline== From the early 1920s, syndicalist movements in most countries began to wane. State repression played a significant role, but movements that were not suppressed also declined. Faced with this decline, syndicalist organizations had three choices: They could stay true to their revolutionary principles and be marginalized. They could give up those principles in order to adapt to new conditions. Finally, they could disband or merge into non-syndicalist organizations. The IWW is an example of the first case. The French CGT, which according to van der Linden and Thorpe was no longer syndicalist after 1914, went the second route.<ref>van der Linden/Thorpe 1990, pg. 4–5, 17–18.</ref>{{refn|group=note|The Swedish SAC initially chose the first option, but as an increasing number of workers left to join the mainstream unions, it changed course and became increasingly reformist. For example, in the 1930s unemployment funds were set up in Sweden, managed by unions but with significant contributions from the state. The SAC initially refused to participate, but the ensuing loss in membership forced the SAC to give in. SAC membership then started to slowly rise.<ref>van der Linden/Thorpe 1990, pg. 18–19.</ref>}} By the end of the 1930s, meaningful legal syndicalist organizations existed only in Bolivia, Chile, Sweden, and Uruguay.<ref>van der Walt 2018, pg. 261.</ref>
===Fascism=== [[Georges Sorel]] played a role in shaping the views of [[Benito Mussolini]] and by extension the wider [[Italian Fascism|Italian fascist]] movement. In March 1921, Sorel wrote that Mussolini was "a man no less extraordinary than Lenin".<ref>[[Jacob Talmon|J. L. Talmon]], ''The Myth of the Nation and the Vision of Revolution: The Origins of Ideological Polarization in the 20th Century'', (University of California Press, 1981), p. 451.</ref> After Sorel's death in 1922, [[Agostino Lanzillo]], a one-time syndicalist leader who had become a fascist, wrote in the Italian fascist review ''Gerarchia'', which was edited by Mussolini: "Perhaps fascism may have the good fortune to fulfill a mission that is the implicit aspiration of the whole oeuvre of the master of syndicalism: to tear away the proletariat from the domination of the Socialist party, to reconstitute it on the basis of spiritual liberty, and to animate it with the breath of creative violence. This would be the true revolution that would mold the forms of the Italy of tomorrow".<ref>[[Zeev Sternhell]], Mario Sznajder, Maia Ashéri, ''The Birth of Fascist Ideology: From Cultural Rebellion to Political Revolution'',(Princeton University Press, 1994), p. 93.</ref> <!-- Flesh out syndicalist influence on Italian fascism: Roberts: The syndicalist tradition and Italian fascism Kadlec: Pound, BLAST, and Syndicalism
Syndicalist analysis of and resistance against fascism/right-wing dictatorships: de Jong Graf: Anarchisten gegen Hitler Something on Spain Italy?, Portugal?, maybe Argentina -->
===Spanish Civil War=== The [[Spanish Revolution of 1936|anarcho-syndicalist revolution]] during the Spanish Civil War resulted in the widespread implementation of anarchist and more broadly socialist organisational principles throughout various portions of the country for two to three years, primarily Catalonia, [[Aragon]], [[Andalusia]] and parts of the [[Levante, Spain|Levante]]. Much of Spain's economy was put under worker control—in anarchist strongholds like Catalonia, the figure was as high as 75%. <!-- Still need good sources -->
===Reasons=== Syndicalism's decline was the result of a number of factors. In Russia, Italy, Portugal, Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands, syndicalist movements were suppressed by authoritarian governments. The IWW in the United States and the Mexican House of the World Worker were weakened considerably by state repression. Syndicalist movements that were not suppressed also declined. According to van der Linden and Thorpe, this was primarily the result of the integration of the working class into capitalist relations. Proletarian families became units of individualized consumption as standards of living increased. This was partly the result of state intervention, particularly the emergence of the welfare state.<ref>van der Linden/Thorpe 1990, pg. 17–18.</ref> Avenues for social reform opened up and the franchise was widened, giving parliamentary reformism legitimacy.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 177–179.</ref> Altena agrees that the state's growing influence in society was decisive for syndicalism's diminished influence. In addition to the welfare state, he refers to the increased significance of national policies, which eroded local autonomy. This made centralized unions able to negotiate national agreements more important and national and parliamentary politics more enticing for workers. They therefore turned to social democracy in larger numbers. Additionally, syndicalism lost out to sports and entertainment in the cultural sphere, according to Altena.<ref>Altena 2010, pg. 217–219.</ref>
Vadim Dam'e adds to this that the development of capitalist production and changes in the division of labor diminished syndicalism's recruitment base.<ref>Altena 2010, pg. 217.</ref> According to authors like Stearns, Edward Shorter, [[Charles Tilly]], and Bob Holton, who deem syndicalism a transitional form of workers' resistance between older craft-based and modern factory-based industry, syndicalism's decline was a product of that transition having been completed and workers being assimilated to capitalist factory discipline.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 158–159.</ref> Darlington counters that syndicalism attracted a variety of workers, not just artisans and skilled workers, but concedes that such changes did play a role in Spain, France, and some other countries.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 159–160</ref>
Several authors claim that syndicalism's demise was the result of workers' inherent pragmatism or conservatism, causing them to only be interested in immediate material gains, rather than long-term goals like overthrowing capitalism. [[Robert Hoxie]], [[Selig Perlman]], and Patrick Renshaw invoke this argument to explain the IWW's decline and Stearns, [[Dermot Keogh]], and [[G. D. H. Cole]] do so with respect to French, Irish, and British syndicalism, respectively.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 145–146.</ref> Darlington disputes the assumption that workers are incapable of developing a revolutionary consciousness. Seeking material gains is not incompatible, he claims, with developing class consciousness, which entails the awareness that workers' material interests conflict with capitalism, particularly in times of crisis.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 151–152.</ref>
According to many Marxists, syndicalism was a reaction to reformism in the labor movement and could not survive without it. The collapse of reformism after the war therefore automatically weakened syndicalism. According [[Eric Hobsbawm]], the biggest reason for syndicalism's decline, however, was the rise of communism. Several communist parties drew their cadres from the syndicalists' ranks. To radical workers the programmatic distinctions between syndicalism and communism were not all that relevant. The key is that after the war communism represented militancy or revolutionary attitude as such.<ref>Hobsbawm 1973, pg. 69, 73–74.</ref> Darlington, too, sees the effects of the Russian Revolution as an important reason for the decline of syndicalism. The emergence of communism highlighted syndicalism's inherent weaknesses: the contradiction of building organizations that sought to be both revolutionary cadre organizations and mass labor unions, the emphasis on economic struggle to the detriment of political action, and the commitment to localism limiting its ability to provide an effective centralized organization and leadership. Bolshevism's overcoming of these limitations and its success in Russia drew syndicalist leaders and members. It also exacerbated splits within the syndicalist camp.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 167.</ref>
==Legacy== Fascist victory in the Spanish Civil War put an end to syndicalism as a mass movement.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 3, 157.</ref> Immediately after World War II, there were attempts to rekindle anarcho-syndicalism in Germany, but they were thwarted by Cold War anti-communism, [[Stalinism]], and a failure to attract newer younger activists.<ref>Bock 1969, pg. 348, Bock 1976, pg. 173–174.</ref> Syndicalists maintained some influence in Latin American labor movements into the 1970s.<ref>Zimmer 2018, pg. 364.</ref> The [[1968 protests|protest movements]] of the late 1960s saw renewed interest in syndicalism by activists in Germany,<ref>Bock 1976, pg. 253, 256.</ref> the US,<ref>Buhle 2005.</ref> and Britain.<ref>Travis 2000.</ref> In the 1980s, in communist Poland, the trade union [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]] (''Solidarność''), though not strictly syndicalist, attracted masses of dissident workers by reviving many syndicalist ideas and practices.<ref>van der Linden/Thorpe 1990, pg. 19.</ref>
[[File:MITING CNT MONTJUÏC.jpg|thumb|right|The Spanish anarchist [[Federica Montseny]] addressing a CNT meeting in Barcelona in 1977 attended by about 300,000 people<ref>Ealham 2015, pg. 203.</ref>]] The IWA exists to this day, but with very little influence. At most, it is a "flicker of history, the custodian of doctrine" according to Wayne Thorpe.<ref>Thorpe 1990, pg. 257–258.</ref> Among its member organizations is the British [[Solidarity Federation]], which was formed in 1994, but has roots going back to 1950.<ref>Barberis/McHugh/Tyldesley 2000, pg. 167–168.</ref> It also includes the German [[Free Workers' Union]] (''Freie Arbeiterinnen- und Arbeiter-Union'', FAU). It was formed to carry on the FAUD's tradition in 1977, but has a membership of just 350 as of 2011.<ref>Drücke 2011, pg. 39, Bundesamt für Verfassungsschutz 2011, pg. 165–166.</ref> Spain has several syndicalist federations, including the CNT, which is still part of the IWA and has around 50,000 members as of 2018.<ref>Cleminson 2012, pg. 412–413, Pascual 2018.</ref> After being defeated in the Civil War, tens of thousands of CNT militants went into exile, mostly in France. In exile, the organization atrophied, with just 5,000 mostly older members by 1960. During [[Spanish transition to democracy|Spain's transition to democracy]], the CNT was revived with a peak membership of over 300,000 in 1978. However, it was soon weakened, first by accusations of having been involved in the [[Scala affair|bombing of a nightclub]], then by a schism.<ref>Ealham 2015, pg. 122, 180–181, 212–215.</ref> Members who favored participation in state-sponsored union elections left and formed an organization they would eventually name the [[General Confederation of Labour (Spain)|General Confederation of Labor]] (''Confederación General del Trabajo'', CGT). Despite these concessions, the CGT still views itself as an anarcho-syndicalist organization and has around 100,000 members as of 2018.<ref>Ealham 2015, pg. 215–216, Pascual 2018.</ref>
According to Darlington, syndicalism left a legacy that was widely admired by labor and political activists in a number of countries. For example, the IWW song "[[Solidarity Forever]]" became part of the American labor movement's canon. The strike wave, including the recruitment of unskilled and foreign-born workers by the [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]], that swept the United States in the 1930s followed in the IWW's footsteps. The tactic of the [[sit-down strike]], made famous by the [[United Auto Workers]] in the [[Flint sit-down strike]], was pioneered by Wobblies in 1906.<ref>Darlington 2008, pg. 278–279.</ref>
Stearns, in his study of French syndicalism, concludes that it was a dismal failure. The radicalism of syndicalist labor leaders, he claims, shocked French workers and the government and thereby weakened the labor movement as a whole. Syndicalism was most popular among workers not yet fully integrated into modern capitalist industry, but most French workers had adapted to this system and accepted it, according to Stearns. Therefore, syndicalism was not able to seriously challenge prevailing conditions or even scare politicians and employers.<ref>Stearns 1971, pg. 103–107.</ref> <!-- To-do Check: Lehning Hirsch/van der Walt Need to find more
Syndicalist influence on labor movement: Darlington Jacques Julliard: Syndicalisme révolutionnaire et révolution étudiante Ponsard: Sur les traces d'un antiparlementarisme syndical Need to find more
Syndicalism after 1968: Gombin: The Origins of Modern Leftism Seidman: The Imaginary Revolution: Parisian Students and Workers in 1968

{{italics title}} '''''The Globalist''''' is a daily [[online magazine]] that "focuses on the [[World economy|economics]], [[international relations|politics]] and [[multiculturalism|culture]]"<ref>[http://www.theglobalist.com/about-us/ The Globalist: About Us], ''The Globalist'', Retrieved November 30, 2006</ref> of [[globalization]]. ''The Globalist'' "aims to provide current and up-to-date news analysis and perspectives on wide-ranging [[global issue]]s that touch all global citizens". Notable columnists include Alexei Bayer & Richard Walker.
Its offices are based in [[Washington, DC]], [[United States]]<ref name=Howitallbegan>[http://www.theglobalist.com/DBWeb/StoryId.aspx?StoryId=4531 The Globalist: How it all began] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061120053520/http://www.theglobalist.com/DBWeb/StoryId.aspx?StoryId=4531 |date=2006-11-20 }}, ''The Globalist'', Retrieved November 30, 2006</ref> and it began publishing on January 3, 2000. ''The Globalist'' was founded by Stephan Richter, who is also its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief. ''The Globalist'', in addition to its English-language flagship, also publishes [[German language|German-]] and [[French language|French-language]] editions.

{{Intelligent Design}} A '''universal probability bound''' is a probabilistic threshold whose existence is asserted by [[William A. Dembski]] and is used by him in his works promoting [[intelligent design]]. It is defined as {{quote|A degree of improbability below which a specified event of that probability cannot reasonably be attributed to chance regardless of whatever probabilitistic resources from the known universe are factored in.<ref>[http://www.iscid.org/encyclopedia/Universal_Probability_Bound ISCID Encyclopedia of Science and Philosophy] (1999)</ref>}}
Dembski asserts that one can effectively estimate a positive value which is a universal probability bound. The existence of such a bound would imply that certain kinds of random events whose probability lies below this value can be assumed not to have occurred in the observable universe, given the resources available in the entire history of the observable universe. Contrapositively, Dembski uses the threshold to argue that the occurrence of certain events cannot be attributed to chance alone. Universal probability bound is then used to argue against random [[evolution]]. However evolution is not based on random events only ([[genetic drift]]), but also on [[natural selection]].
The idea that events with fantastically small, but positive probabilities, are ''effectively'' negligible<ref>Negligible means having probability zero. Effectively negligible means, roughly, that in some [[operational definition|operational]] sense or in some computational sense, the event is indistinguishable from a negligible one.</ref> was discussed by the [[France|French]] [[mathematician]] [[Émile Borel]] primarily in the context of [[cosmology]] and [[statistical mechanics]].<ref>Émile Borel, ''Elements of the Theory of Probability'' (translated by John Freund), Prentice Hall, 1965, Chapter 6. See also [http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/abioprob/borelfaq.html Citations from Borel's articles].</ref> However, there is no widely accepted scientific basis for claiming that certain positive values are ''universal'' cutoff points for effective negligibility of events. Borel, in particular, was careful to point out that negligibility was relative to a model of probability for a specific physical system.<ref>Though Dembski credits Borel for the idea, there is clear evidence that Borel, following accepted scientific practice in the foundations of statistics, was not referring to a ''universal'' bound, independent of the statistical model used.</ref><ref>Cobb, L. (2005) ''[http://www.aetheling.com/essays/Borel.html Borel's Law and Creationism]'', Aetheling Consultants.</ref>
Dembski appeals to [[cryptography|cryptographic]] practice in support of the concept of the universal probability bound, noting that cryptographers have sometimes compared the security of encryption algorithms against [[brute force attack]]s by the likelihood of success of an adversary utilizing computational resources bounded by very large physical constraints. An example of such a constraint might be obtained for example, by assuming that every atom in the observable universe is a computer of a certain type and these computers are running through and testing every possible key. Although universal measures of security are used much less frequently than asymptotic ones<ref>For a precise definition of effective negligibility in cryptography, see [[Michael Luby]], ''Pseudorandomness and Cryptographic Applications'', Princeton Computer Science Series, 1996.</ref> and the fact that a keyspace is very large may be less relevant if the cryptographic algorithm used has vulnerabilities which make it susceptible to other kinds of attacks,<ref>Though Dembski repeatedly appeals to cryptography in support of the concept of the universal probability bound, in practice cryptographers hardly use measures which are in any way related to it. A more useful concept is that of [[work factor]]. See p. 44, A. J. Menezes, P. C. van Oorschot, S. A. Vanstone, ''Handbook of Applied Cryptography'', CRC Press, 1996.</ref> asymptotic approaches and directed attacks would, by definition, be unavailable under chance-based scenarios such as those relevant to Dembski's universal probability bound. As a result, Dembski's appeal to cryptography is best understood as referring to brute force attacks, rather than directed attacks.
==Dembski's estimate==
Dembski's original value for the universal probability bound is 1 in 10<sup>150</sup>, derived as the inverse of the product of the following approximate quantities:<ref>William A. Dembski (1998). ''[[The Design Inference]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=zvToAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA213&dq=dembski+%22universal+probability+bound%22+%22the+design+inference%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rxQJVey9NYSkgwSGnoOwBA&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=dembski%20%22universal%20probability%20bound%22%20%22the%20design%20inference%22&f=false pg 213, section 6.5]</ref><ref>William A. Dembski (2004). ''[[The Design Revolution|The Design Revolution: Answering the Toughest Questions About Intelligent Design]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=sKVqpXqE0VwC&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=universal+probability+bound&source=bl&ots=0vtqjR1_3f&sig=bpCBVhooWOjlRkELvtEkv2XniHM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kucIVeXEAsaogwTUtISwBQ&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=universal%20probability%20bound&f=false pg 85]</ref>
* 10<sup>80</sup>, the number of elementary particles in the [[observable universe]]. * 10<sup>45</sup>, the maximum rate per second at which transitions in physical states can occur (i.e., the inverse of the [[Planck time]]). * 10<sup>25</sup>, a [[Billion (word)|billion]] times longer than the typical estimated age of the universe in seconds.
Thus, 10<sup>150</sup> = 10<sup>80</sup> × 10<sup>45</sup> × 10<sup>25</sup>. Hence, this value corresponds to an upper limit on the number of physical events that could possibly have occurred in the observable part of the universe since the [[big bang]].
Dembski has recently (as of 2005) refined his definition to be the inverse of the product of two different quantities:<ref>William A. Dembski (2005). "[http://www.designinference.com/documents/2005.06.Specification.pdf "Specification: The Pattern That Signifies Intelligence (382k PDF)]".</ref>
* An upper bound on the computational resources of the universe in its entire history. This is estimated by [[Seth Lloyd]] as 10<sup>120</sup> elementary logic operations on a register of 10<sup>90</sup> bits<ref>Seth Lloyd, ''[https://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0110141 Computational Capacity of the Universe]'', arXiv:quant-ph/0110141 v1</ref><ref>The number 10<sup>90</sup> seems to play no role in Dembski's analysis, On page 23 of ''Specification: The Pattern That Signifies Intelligence'', Dembski says :"Lloyd has shown that 10<sup>120</sup>constitutes the maximal number of bit operations that the known, observable universe could have performed throughout its entire multi-billion year history."</ref> * The (variable) rank complexity of the event under consideration.<ref>The rank complexity is Dembski's φ function which ranks patterns in order of their [[Kolmogorov complexity|descriptive complexity]]. See [[specified complexity]].</ref>
If the latter quantity equals 10<sup>150</sup>, then the overall universal probability bound corresponds to the original value.
== The observable universe == Dembski's estimate is dependent on the number of protons in the observable universe. Given that the observable universe is only a lower bound to the size of the entire universe, it is entirely possible that the total number of protons in the entire universe is very many times more than used by Dembski. For this reason, Dembski's probability bound is not a limit to what may or may not plausibly happen in the entire universe, only the fraction of it that is observable from earth.<ref>Citation needed</ref>

'''White House visitor logs''', also known as the White House Worker and Visitor Entry System (WAVE), are the [[guestbook]] records of individuals visiting the [[White House]] to meet with the [[President of the United States]] or other White House officials.
== History == The release of some logs to the public have been a goal of, and can be credited to the pressure from, [[Watchdog journalism|watchdog groups]] concerned with possible undue influence of [[Lobbying|lobbyists]] over the US government.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/data/White-House-Publishes-5-Million-Visitor-Access-Records.html|title=White House Publishes 5.02 Million Visitor Access Records|website=www.govtech.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-20}}</ref> Groups such as [[Judicial Watch]], [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington|CREW]], and [https://nsarchive.gwu.edu/ The National Security Archive] have been suing the government to release such logs under the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] since at least the early 2000s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-08-30/secret-service-must-produce-white-house-visitor-records|title=Secret Service Must Produce Some White House Records – Bloomberg|date=2016-11-15|access-date=2017-06-20|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161115084148/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-08-30/secret-service-must-produce-white-house-visitor-records|archivedate=2016-11-15|df=}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.publicintegrity.org/2011/04/13/4115/white-house-visitor-logs-riddled-holes|title=White House visitor logs riddled with holes|date=2011-04-13|website=Center for Public Integrity|access-date=2017-06-20}}</ref> The [[Presidency of Bill Clinton|Clinton]] and [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush]] administrations refused to release visitor records to the public, arguing they are part of presidential communications and not public records.<ref name=":1" /> The [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]], however, after initially following the same policy,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/31373407/ns/politics-white_house/t/obama-blocks-list-visitors-white-house/#.WUjPfOWGNhE|title=Obama blocks list of visitors to White House|date=2009-06-16|work=msnbc.com|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en}}</ref> eventually reversed it and by mid-2009 released the visitor logs as part of its stated commitment to [[Open government|government transparency]], under the White House Voluntary Disclosure Policy.<ref name=":0" /> It was the first US administration to release those logs to the public.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/blog/2015/12/30/more-502-million-records-released|title=More than 5.02 Million Records Released|date=2015-12-30|work=whitehouse.gov|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/statement-president-first-time-disclosure-policy-white-house-visitor-logs|title=Statement from the President on the First Time Disclosure Policy for White House Visitor Logs {{!}} whitehouse.gov|date=2017-01-18|access-date=2017-06-20|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118000633/https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/statement-president-first-time-disclosure-policy-white-house-visitor-logs|archivedate=2017-01-18|df=}}</ref> The logs were nonetheless redacted to remove sensitive meetings (such as visits by potential Supreme Court nominees) and purely personal guests.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/VoluntaryDisclosure|title=White House Voluntary Disclosure Policy Visitor Access Records|date=2015-08-27|work=whitehouse.gov|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en}}</ref> Logs for the period between January 20 and September 15, 2009, are subject to different policy and require specific requests.<ref name=":3" />
The [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]] withdrew its support for release of the logs, and is not making visitor logs available to the public, though some comments suggest the logs could be made available "five years after Trump leaves office".<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4740499/white-house-visitor-logs-public-record-trump/|title=The White House Will Keep Its Visitor Logs Secret|last=Miller|first=Zeke J.|website=Time|access-date=2017-06-20}}</ref><ref name=":5"/> This has led to several groups suing the government again, demanding the release of such logs, which should be seen as a matter of public record.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/04/13/523774821/as-trump-continues-mar-a-lago-trips-watchdogs-want-to-know-who-s-joining-him|title=As Trump Continues Mar-A-Lago Trips, Watchdogs Want To Know Who's Joining Him|website=NPR.org|access-date=2017-06-20}}</ref><ref name=":5"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Breaking News: Judge Lets Secret Service Hide White House Visitor Logs|editor=Lauren Harper|publisher=[[National Security Archive]]|url=https://nsarchive.gwu.edu/news/foia/2018-07-27/breaking-news-judge-lets-secret-service-hide-white-house-visitor-logs|accessdate=August 2, 2018|date=July 27, 2018}}</ref>
== Analysis == [[File:Dave Cote Headshot.jpg|thumb|[[David M. Cote]] (Chairman and CEO of [[Honeywell|Honeywell International]]) was the most frequent business visitor to the White House during the Obama administration.]] While Obama's release of the logs was generally praised by transparency activists,<ref name=":1" /> the [[Sunlight Foundation]] noted, "The voluntary system can be too easily circumvented. Because it only captures visitors to the White House, if an administration official wishes to keep a meeting with a lobbyist secret, he or she merely has to schedule it at a nearby location" and "Phone calls are also used to avoid disclosure".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/policy/one-pagers/disclose-all-lobbyist-meetings-white-house-staff/|title=Disclose All Lobbyist Meetings With White House Staff|work=Sunlight Foundation|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en-US}}</ref> Omission of significant visits was criticised by other groups.<ref name=":4" /> ''Time'' noted that "The Obama-era process allowed the White House Counsel’s office to unilaterally redact records of those visiting the complex for any reason. The Obama Administration, for instance, took a wide-ranging view of what were considered personal events hosted by the Obamas, leaving off celebrity sightings and meetings with top donors." The visitors could request to have their records shielded from public through a simple checkbox on the visitor form.<ref name=":5"/>
A 2017 study showed that companies whose executives have met the president report a raise of their share values, by approximately 0.5% following a month or two after the disclosure of the meeting. The authors note that direct causation is difficult to prove, but it is likely that investors view such news as indication that companies will perform better, for example winning more government procurement contracts.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21722217-white-house-visitor-logs-help-show-lobbying-pays-when-bosses-visit-white-house-their|title=When bosses visit the White House, their firms make more money|website=The Economist|access-date=2017-06-20}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Jeffrey|last2=Huang|first2=Jiekun|title=All the President's Friends: Political Access and Firm Value |work=NBER Working Paper No. 23356 |doi=10.3386/w23356 |date=April 2017}}</ref> That study identified 2,286 meetings between corporate executives and federal government officials with the top three most frequent visitors for that period being [[David M. Cote]] (Chairman and CEO of [[Honeywell|Honeywell International]], 30 visits), [[Jeff Immelt|Jeffrey R. Immelt]] (Executive Chairman and CEO of [[General Electric]], 22 visits) and [[Roger Altman|Roger C. Altman]] (Executive Chairman of [[Evercore Partners|EverCore Partners]], 21 visits).<ref name=":0" /> The top three most frequent visitees by corporate executives in that period were [[Valerie Jarrett]] (Senior Advisor to the President, 107 visits), [[Jeffrey Zients|Jeff Zients]] (Assistant to the President for Economic Policy and Director of the National Economic Council, 103 visits), and the President himself (100 visits).<ref name=":0" />

{{Italic title}} [[Image:Gérôme Eminence grise 1873.jpg|300px|thumb|[[François Leclerc du Tremblay]] is the figure in black depicted descending the staircase in this oil painting by [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]]]] An '''''éminence grise''''' ({{IPA-fr|eminɑ̃s ɡʁiz}}) or '''grey eminence''' is a powerful decision-maker or adviser who operates "behind the scenes", or in a non-public or unofficial capacity.
== Origin == This phrase originally referred to [[François Leclerc du Tremblay]], the right-hand man of [[Cardinal Richelieu]].<ref>{{cite book|last = O'Connell|first = D.P.|year = 1968|title = Richelieu|location = New York |publisher = The World Publishing Company}}</ref> Leclerc was a [[Order of Friars Minor Capuchin|Capuchin friar]] who was renowned for his beige robe attire, as beige was termed "grey" in that era. The style ''[[His Eminence]]'' is used to address or refer to a [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinal]] in the [[Roman Catholic Church]].<ref>[[Talk:Éminence grise#Very good article|Historical reference to address in the Roman Catholic Church]]</ref> Although Leclerc never achieved the rank of cardinal, those around him addressed him as such in deference to the considerable influence this "grey" friar held over "His Eminence the Cardinal".<ref>{{Cite book|last=Mould |first=Michael |title=The Routledge Dictionary of Cultural References in Modern French |year=2011 |publisher=Taylor & Francis |location=New York |isbn=978-1-136-82573-6 |page=149 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x-FNTmUwfpEC&pg=PA149 |accessdate=15 June 2012 }}</ref>
Leclerc is referred to in several popular works. [[Aldous Huxley]] wrote an English biography of Leclerc entitled, ''[[Grey Eminence]]''. There is also an 1873 painting by [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]], ''L'Éminence Grise'', which depicts him descending the grand staircase of the [[Palais-Royal|Palais Cardinal]] and the deference shown to him by others present. Leclerc is referred to in [[Alexandre Dumas]]' ''[[The Three Musketeers]]'' as the character Father Joseph, a powerful associate of Richelieu and one to be feared.
== Historical examples == * [[Jia Nanfeng|Empress Jia]] and [[Empress Dowager Cixi]] are two examples of women who essentially ruled [[History of China#Imperial China|Imperial Chinese]] dynasties. As women were barred from reigning in their own right, the [[history of China]] is replete with cases of [[Women in ancient and imperial China|women exercising political power]] through their male relatives.<ref name=mcmahon>{{cite book | last1=McMahon | first1=Keith | title=Women Shall Not Rule: Imperial Wives and Concubines in China from Han to Liao | page=16 | date=2013 | publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] | location=[[Lanham, Maryland]] | isbn=9781442222908 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gc_3IXkwG3QC&printsec=frontcover | accessdate=28 February 2017}}</ref> * The Italian Christian Democratic leader [[Giulio Andreotti]] was often seen as the ''éminence grise'' of governments even when he was not actually Prime Minister.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9dRZODoB-xUC&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=andreotti+eminenza+grigia&source=bl&ots=AdDIM_ThJZ&sig=a_Te06aOvPmoN9XR2tT9LozZS9Y&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwir7aPbq47WAhUIUhQKHb5YDekQ6AEIVjAN#v=onepage&q=andreotti%20eminenza%20grigia&f=false Andreotti. La vita di un uomo politico, la storia di un'epoca.]</ref> * [[Dick Cheney]] was described as an ''éminence grise'' of the [[George W. Bush]] administration, "a powerful but uncompromising politician with the ear of the president" regarding matters of national security and foreign policy.<ref name=USNews>{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/060123/23cheney.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060117052051/http://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/060123/23cheney.htm|date=January 23, 2006|archivedate=January 17, 2006|title=The Cheney Factor: How the scars of public life shaped the vice president's unyielding view of executive power|first=Kenneth T.|last=Walsh|work=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|quote=[[Lawrence Wilkerson]], a Cheney critic said: "The power behind the throne — an eminence grise — that's what Dick Cheney has become."}}</ref> * Former diplomat and policy maker [[Dennis Ross]] was "viewed as the éminence grise, a sort of [[Grigori Rasputin|Rasputin]] who casts a spell over secretaries of state and presidents", according to Middle East experts who worked with him during the Reagan, Clinton, Bush, and Obama administrations.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Helene|last2=Landler|first2=Mark|title=Obama's Peace Tack Contrasts With Key Aide, Friend of Israel|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/21/world/middleeast/21ross.html?hp|website=The New York Times|accessdate=22 January 2017|date=21 May 2011}}</ref> * [[John Dee]] is sometimes considered an ''éminence grise''. Officially, he was the court astrologer to [[Elizabeth I]] but exercised more power as an overall advisor to the Queen. *[[Joseph Stalin]] was frequently called an ''éminence grise'' by [[Leon Trotsky]] whom he defeated in the succession struggles for Soviet leadership following Lenin's death in 1924.<ref>Leon Trotsky, "Stalin: An Appraisal of the Man and His Influence"</ref>{{better source|date=November 2017}} *Adolf Hitler's private secretary [[Martin Bormann]] was nicknamed the ''Brown Eminence''.
